reviewText:
Possibly one of the strangest and greatest games ever made.

This is a story about a man named Stanley ... but honestly it really is a story about a Narrator and the exquisite mental torture he puts you through trying to figure out why. 'Why what?' I hear you ask. No! Just simply 'why'. A question you will constantly ask yourself, and probably never answer well enough to feel satisfied.

So what is the game? Well you play Stanley, who works in an office. And one day Stanley realises everyone else has disappeared and it is up to him to find out why ... or is it? You see the problem with describing this game is whilst there are many different endings, none of them seem to be 'the right one', or perhaps all of them are.

Yes I realise this review is not even slightly helpful in undertand what this game is, and wether or not you should buy it.  So here it is: Buy this game and play it! It is something that everyone should experience. Love it or hate it .... you really should try it.


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=io3c1USf0V4&list=PLE7DlYarj-Dd0n0idk-siWmqIFcXCzZ48&index=2
voteText: 351 of 380 people (92%) found this review helpful 61 people found this review funny

reviewText:
OverviewThe Stanley Parable is a one of a kind game. You play as Stanley, an employee that has to press buttons. When suddenly, you stop and head out your office. A narrator describes your adventure and it's up to you to listen to him or not. Explore the office building and make different choices every playthrough and unlock all of the many endings possible!

The Pros:Beautiful - The graphics are decent, the lightning glorious, and walking through the building is pleasant to the eye.

Choices - The best thing a game can do for you is let you be in control. The Stanley Parable makes you make your own story, every step of the way, and unlocking a different ending every time. Such decisions include taking the left or right door, going to the meeting or not, or turning off the evil machine... or not. Every action has a thing to say for the ending.

Comical - The narrator says things that are sometimes very funny, the way he reacts when you disobey him and the scenes you encounter have some very rich monologue.

Deep - It might not look like this the first time you play, but as you uncover different endings you will see the hidden meaning behind Stanley's story. The writing is very cleverly done, the existance of the narrator poses further questions, and the very nature of reality bends amongst different endings.
The Cons:Repetitive up to a point - As the story forks at different intersections, you are bound to repeat parts of it until you reach the branching point. Some of the paths require waiting for long narrations to play, so you might become a little impatient along the process.

Unconventional Achievements - Most achievements require a degree of witt to figure out what they want (or read a guide) but there are some that are really unnecessary, such as playing the game for the entire duration of a Tuesday, implying either BIOS Time Changing or leaving the PC idle for 24 hours, the Unachiveable, which requires configuration file tweaks and the Go Outside which makes you not play for... 5 years. Of course, circumventable with a little sly techniques, but they are not achievements related to the game. They don't track progress or skill, they're just there to mess with you and waste your time.
Conclusion:The Stanley Parable stand out amongst the rest of pshycological narratives and really puts the player in a position of power over his destiny, or at least gives him a very powerful delusion about it. Buy with confidence, it is an enjoyable experience.

If you enjoyed this review and want to see more of my work, consider joining my group and follow my curator page! Link to the right!Jad's List - Curator Group

reviewText:
At it's core, it's a playful mockery of video game storytelling themes.  The writing is clever, and the narration is charming, while also managing to be just a little unsettling.  It's a game, so much in that you control movement and press buttons.  But there isn't any combat, and the freedom of choice is just an illusion (which is kinda the point).  It's meant to be played over and over again, just to see the different reactions you can get from the game.  And there are many many reactions to find.

And if this doesn't sound like something you'd want to spend any time with, you can always treat it like a really obscure easter egg hunt.  Because there's a ton of those too.  If you are like me, and you try to break a game just for fun, you might find out that this game considers it a legitimate storytelling branch.

And if that doesn't sell it to you either, you can consider it a narrator annoyance simulator.  It's something for everyone, provided you like these three things.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is a narrative story that stars, you guessed it, Stanley. Stanley works in a dead end job carrying out mindless tasks; and the story is told by one of the best narratives I have ever heard. Graphics isn't an important feature here, but that being said, it looks really nice.

The design of the world is very well done, you are essentially in an office building, but it does a very clever thing where you can sometimes be walking around in a circle, and then all of a sudden the world changes, and you are somewhere else. This made the experience feel more real to me. You can make this game as easy or as difficult as you want. There is fifteen different stories and endings to the Stanley Parable, each of them is amazingly written, probably one of, if not the best story in gaming I've experienced and well worth playing.  It has taken me almost seven hours to play through all of the endings, and do all but one of the achievements. After you have played all of the endings though, there is probably no need to go replay any of the game again.

Is the game worth ¬£9, 99, sure? For about seven hours of gameplay and the amount of fun I had playing it; you cannot miss out on The Stanley Parable. This is now in my top ten favourite games of all time.

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oADQMrDfeXI

The Stanley Parable began life as a mod for Half Life 2 and was recently updated and released on steam with achievements, more story branches and shiny new visuals. It places players in the mundane shoes of Stanley, a corporate desk jockey who is placed in an office in front of a computer where he punches buttons for a living. One day his monitor goes blank and the other corporate drones that he shares the office building with disappear and so begins your Journey as Stanley.  Being the dull chap that he is, Stanley himself doesn't offer much ion the area of entertainment, but a charming English narrator provides the personality and humor necessary to make The Stanley Parable an enjoyable experience. The narrator provides player with instructions, becoming almost like a GPS device that has confused itself for a raconteur.

Where most games are about following the rules, The Stanley Parable is best enjoyed when breaking them. If the narrator says go right, you will certainly find more satisfaction in taking a left and listening as the narrator's knickers become twisted by your wanton disobedience. By taking these divergent paths you will find yourself faced with one of the game's 15 different conclusions. Each conclusion revels something a bit different about Stanley and they range from conspiratorial to surreal. The game plays a few tricks on you by repeating rooms endlessly or swapping out props on the fly truing an office into an apartment space. All of this is rendered in a simple and clean visual style. The color palette is muted to reflect just what a dull and miserable existence our pal Stanley has and the props are equally generic creating an appropriately stodgy atmosphere. As advertised the texture work adds far more detail than could be found in the original mod and overall the HD remix has much greater visual appeal.

So is The Stanley Parable a biting satire of the way in which modern games tell their story by allowing us to control a character on a predetermined path where deviation is punished? Is it a parody of the life of the average key punching office drone? Or, is it just an excuse to have a rather cheeky British man tell us what to do? The answer is that it's all of these... and none of them. It's a game that will give each of it's players a different take away. Each playthrough lasts between 15 minutes and a half hour. This doesn't sound like a lot of playtime, and it isn't but there is a tremendous degree of satisfaction in finding new ways to get the game to react to what you are or, in some cases, are not doing. Seeing all 15 endings without consulting a guide will probably take around 3 hours. These 15 endings are not Mass Effect 3 style endings either‚Äîthey are wholly unique and there are a couple of treats for gamers to be uncovered. Ultimately, The Stanley Parable will not be everyone's cup of tea, but it holds a very special spot in the gaming landscape. It's a testament to satire and unconventional design as well as manipulating gamer's expectations. In short it's the antithesis of it's key punching dullard protagonist.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is a really good meta-game. The game investigates the relationship and interaction between the character, the player (you), the narrator and the game developers. (Almost) The entire game is set in a dull Source-made office landscape, yet managed to keep my interest all along because of the intriguing and deceiving narration.

You can play through it in probably half an hour on your first go, but the game has tons of different endings, and you can approach the game in lots of different ways. I played it for roughly 2,5 hours, and I believe I got all the endings, or at least as many as I fancy for now.

Give it at go!

reviewText:
Stanley Parable is a unique, if not atypical game. You play as employee number 427; an employee who only pushes buttons as per the instructions of his superiors. Stanley, however, does not receive any orders one day, therefore, he gets up from his desk and starts investigating what exactly has happened.

And this is where you take control of him in this FPS which uses the well-known game engine called Source. Our protagonist immediately notices that nobody else is present in the office - he passes empty cubicles and corridors trying to find the answers.

There are no weapons in this game. No NPCs you can interact with. No objectives. No goals. Stanley Parable is about exploration. And this exploration, this journey of our white-collar worker is accompanied by the narrator's voice.

However, you will notice that the narrator tells Stanley, in advance, which door he is supposed to take. But you can refuse the command and go to the direction you desire. And this is the most crucial part of this game: it is about choices. Your choices.

And these choices can yield you at least a dozen endings. Endings that are funny, serious, sarcastic and some are even meant to be no more than mere easter eggs.

This is not something you'll spend dozens of hours with. No, Stanley Parable can be completed in a mere 30 minutes, still, it's worth the journey and the appreciation.

reviewText:
Before you buy the game:

1. Play the Demo first.
2. Avoid buying it if you suffer any of these:

Decidophobia- Fear of making decisions.
Ambulophobia- Fear of walking.
Ergophobia- Fear of work.
Cyberphobia- Fear of computers or working on a computer.
Lygophobia- Fear of darkness.
Scoptophobia- Fear of being seen or stared at.
Testophobia- Fear of taking tests.
Atychiphobia- Fear of failure.
Dementophobia- Fear of insanity.
Apeirophobia- Fear of infinity.
Eleutherophobia- Fear of freedom.
Atelophobia- Fear of imperfection.
Soteriophobia - Fear of dependence on others.
Psychophobia- Fear of mind.
Anablephobia- Fear of looking up.
Stanleyphobia - Fear of the name Stanley
Claustrophobia- Fear of confined spaces.
Ouranophobia- Fear of heaven.
Anglophobia- Fear of England or English culture, etc.
Astrophobia- Fear of stars or celestial space.
Alektorophobia- Fear of chickens.
Rectophobia- Fear of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• or rectal diseases.

By the way, dont read this review if you suffer Phobophobia- Fear of phobias.

reviewText: The Stanley Parable is a ground-up remake of the cult Half-Life 2 mod and expands it in a dozen directions without altering its fundamentals. It is one of those first-person walking" games in which you wander around a completely non-violent experience exploring the environment and unravelling the story
recommended: an office worker. Stanley has the job to push buttons on command until some day those commands abruptly stop. Stanley is leaving his desk to investigate
hoursPlayed: his actions are directed by a narrator who guides him through the office facility to discover the truth.\nThe Stanley Parable is a game about walking from A to B. As you approach a pair of doors
voteText: the narrator will indicate that Stanley takes the left one. Whether you do and how you decide to follow up your revolt or acquiescence
helpfulPercent: tilts the game towards wildly different conclusions. A playthrough may only take minutes
votesHelpful: but The Stanley Parable has a lot of choices and a lot of different endings. It will take a few hours to see everything and every ending.\nAt each of the game's many intersections
votesTotal: you can follow the narrator's instruction or ignore it and face the consequences of your petty resistance. Each combination of choices leads to something unique. Some of these "endings" are lighthearted
votesFunny: some are absurd and many centre around the narrator's attempts to get back to his story.\nThe Stanley Parable has not the best Source Engine graphics. Many of the environments are bland
commentsCount: but deliberately so. Delightful hidden details show their faces everywhere if you are willing to look.\nThe best part of The Stanley Parable is the voice acting of the omnipotent Narrator. He plays witness to every move which do you make. From a kindly
column16: yet firm
column17: guiding hand at the start of the game to an acerbic wit if you ignore him
column18: the Narrator really adds a soul to the world of The Stanley Parable.\nI enjoyed the game and I would recommend the game to people who want to try out something different instead of the normal games

column20: but you should then be able to decide if the game is something for you or not.\nIf you should still be unsure

reviewText:
I didn't know what to write about in my review, so here's a recipe for pancakes instead:

1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 1/2 teaspoons baking powder
1 teaspoon salt
1 tablespoon white sugar
1 1/4 cups milk
1 egg
3 tablespoons butter, melted

1. In a large bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt and sugar. Make a well in the center and pour in the milk, egg and melted butter; mix until smooth.

2. Heat a lightly oiled griddle or frying pan over medium high heat. Pour or scoop the batter onto the griddle, using approximately 1/4 cup for each pancake. Brown on both sides and serve hot.

reviewText:
There really isn't anything that you can say about this except that it isn't a game.  Anyone buying it as such will be sorely disappointed.  What it IS is a brilliant commentary on not just gaming culture, but the thought processes of gamers themselves.

It really is brilliantly done, and superbly executed.  As a gamer, I felt a strange air of danger and menace throughout, as if something was going kick off and lead to some sort of battle for survival, and the game plays with this notion throughout, offering a number of different endings".  The "good" ending (which I won't spoil) is a very well observed satire on game design and player choice.

It really is hard to write anything about the game without spoiling something!  All I can really say is - it's not for everyone.  Some people may look down on people who don't enjoy it or don't get it and that's not entirely fair.  The ideas and concept explored aren't hugely complex
date: but probably require a high level of self awareness and self criticism on the part of the player.\n\nIn summary - this is a sublime mix of art

reviewText: This game left me with a sense of emotional insecurity like a hole in my heart. With that being said, this is one of the most creative and incredible plots that I've ever had the privilege to play. It pulls you into an ever changing relationship with the narrator that becomes the most important part of the game. Put simply, fear+humor+sadness+beauty+confusion-everything you know about gaming=The Stanley Parable.

reviewText:
This short review/analysis contains spoilers about the game. Stop reading if you want to have a fresh experience with the game. Everything below is my speculation, don't take them as definitive facts.
The Stanley Parable is everything and beyond video games. It's a giant commentary on todays game development philosophy. Throughout its unexpected span and twisty narrative, it has a clear message - there are problems with narrative in video games, which we have not addressed yet.
In recent years we have seen a great amount of open world/sand box games. But there hasn't been shortage in linear games with strict control over players actions. Invisible walls or direct threatening by the game if you go off the map, even in scenarios where the level design suggests more freedom than the available and, but not limited to - bugging out the whole game or level by reaching unexpected locations are common practices in multiplayer and even in singleplayer games since decades.
The layout of the office (which is briefly explained in the museum, behind the scenes room) is designed and created with the mind that the dialogue and attention span of the player would balance and lead to the first sense of conflict - the two doors.
This first dilemma is presented geniously - with a confident and calm voice. At this point the narrator is still following the hardcoded written script. Which is what I describe as the main and simple story the whole Stanely Parable is based around - there is a problem, the protagonist decides to end the tyranny of the evil force and it concludes with a happy ending.
The simple story has cartoonish elements. Toward the end of it, it cultivates exaggerated tone and willingly becomes boring, it's purpose is to show the most basic and at the same time intriguing story. But only if the player obeys/follows the steps the given by the narrator.
Not obeying the narrative, leads to all sorts of interesting results, which ultimately don't explain the whole picture of The Stanley Parable, which is left to players imagination. The game doesn't feel the need to address any of the questions which the audience asks frantically after playing it. The same happened in the demonstration, particularly in the 'Escape elevator' sequence.
Throughout the exploration/ending hunting there are many sections where the nature of narration and design in games is examined and often made fun out of.
Many actions, which are not part of the hardcoded script, of the player are directly commentated by the narrator.
Like the 'Broom closet' - this room has no place in the whole game. In traditional game narrative it would be a waste of time - there isn't a collectable or extra life and if the player decides to explore it, the game would punish him for doing so. But here, the comedic nature of TSP rewards the player for paying attention to it, even if it is only a piece of dialogue.
Achievements are another device with which the The Stanley Parable mocks the current video game industry. Take the 'Click on door 430 five times' for example  - a great way to address the ridiculous amount of pointless achievements in some games. Or 'Unachievable' - an obvious phantom which doesn't have a solution. It is created solely that particular part of the player audience grinds through the game, desperately trying to get it.
So, how does The Stanley Parable get away with being so rude to every aspect in the modern video game industry, while being part of it?
Its complete and constant self awareness makes TSP simply perfect. It is written and executed exceptionally well. It deflects most of the criticism, directed at it, simply by being one.

reviewText:
This isn't a review so much...as it's more of an...observation.

When I bought this game, I expected a quirky, fun, and curious adventure.

Why then, throughout every ending, was I constantly on edge? This is not a horror game. In fact, there is only one single part in the entire game I would say could actually jump you, and it's an error noise.

But...something within me was bothered during my gameplay. Was it the blank interior? The lack of music?
Maybe it was the pure silence you experienced while awaiting the narrator to provide you with your next choice.

No. I think it's more.

There's something else about this game. Something I noticed from the start. Something about this game is...wrong. It's like you are being watched. The entire time. And, even more disturbingly, you discover in one of the endings that this is entirely possible.

This is not a horror game.

And yet...

...it's something else entirely.

reviewText:
A gem in my opinion!

This is one of those games that I actually tell myself I‚Äôm so glad that I played. The concept of this game is great to me.

You play as Stanley. A man who works in a mundane job pushing buttons all day. Orders come through to his screen to push buttons and he does as told. One day, Stanley realises no orders are coming through, and that no one else is in the office. He gets up to see what‚Äôs going on.

That‚Äôs where we come in! You navigate Stanley around a very seemingly linear office, and quickly discover that you have a narrator dictating everything that you do, before you do it. Of course, leaving you room to either play out what he says, or go against it. You come to various paths and crossroads and are given the choice to either do what you‚Äôre told or not.

What I love about this game is how it plays on pure human curiosity. If you go one way, you usually wonder‚Ä¶ but what would happen if I went the other way? There is many endings to the game, and as the narrator goes on with his story, you wonder what is true. If anything you‚Äôre being told is true, what the real story to the game is or if there even is one. It gets you thinking, and I love a game that‚Äôll make me think!

I enjoyed this game very much. I have an odd ‚Äúfear‚Äù, kind of, of missing or losing things. So being given a game with many paths, endings and different things to find, admittedly I did OCD over it a bit and actually went as far as drawing myself a map (Don‚Äôt judge me). But it was a lot of fun! I had a great time playing this game and think it is something anyone could enjoy.

The graphics are nice. I wasn‚Äôt aware before, but this game actually started as a Half-Life 2 mod. As a standalone game I think it did really well for itself.

The characters are amazing. I love both Stanley, the narrator and the odd ‚Äúrelationship‚Äù they have with each other (Even though Stanley never speaks). The voice casting for the narrator is on point, I honestly couldn‚Äôt imagine the character any other way. He‚Äôs well-spoken and has a great charm about him. The narrator in ways kind of ‚Äútrolls‚Äù you a bit with how he tries to keep you on track or how he reacts when you go against him. But he‚Äôs a great character and that is important for a game so dependent on that character being entertaining.

The humour in this game was something I did enjoy quite a bit. The way things are done and played out I was quite impressed with.

In terms of achievements, a few can be a little tedious, but in ways you ain‚Äôt even mad. As said before the game can ‚Äútroll‚Äù you at times and it does so even more through the achievements. I would say that it‚Äôs still easy to 100%, but there is a few that you kind of need to ‚Äúcheat‚Äù to achievement. For example, an achievement titled ‚ÄúGo outside‚Äù, your task being to ‚Äúnot play The Stanley Parable for 5 years‚Äù. Which, come on!

All in all, I love this game and really think you should give it a try. If you like a good bit of humour and like your curiosity being tempted I think this game is a good one for that.


TL ; DR : A great and unique game that tests your curiosity and gets you thinking. It has many endings to offer and generally is fun, definitely try it!

reviewText:
I've been playing games for many a year now and many of these games have had lines in them. Many games have had truly great lines in them. Who could forget that one to the left of the web on Tempest? The one that stretches out from the explosion in Minestorm? Ah, the beautiful lines that you crash your bike into in a game of Light Cycles. They were good lines. And as time went past, games got more lines. Then one day we decided that lines weren't enough and we had some triangles and we put the triangles together and we made videogames with triangles instead of dots and instead of lines and oh, what did we lose? But it was OK because then lines came back into fashion around 2006 and they sort of glowed too. Glowy lines! We made games with glowy lines and the lines in those games were great too. I didn't like the green ones so much in Geometry Wars but they were trying y'know?

Years and years of great lines and yet, it took until 2013 for us to get THE BEST LINE. Ladies and everyone else out there, The Adventure Line is the best line in all of videogames. Let us take a moment to let that sink in. The. Adventure. Line.

The Adventure Line is the best line. Sing it from the rooftops because this is -the- Oscar worthy line performances, the BAFTA of road markings, the Laurence Olivier award of yellow. Thank you, Adventure Line. You're amazing. Just great.

reviewText:
I was very reluctant to give this game a negative review because I have mixed feelings about it, but ultimately, I would not recommend it to anybody else, especially not for it's full asking price. After playing it through a few times, I believe that the game just simply isn't worth the money, perhaps on a very generous sale, but even ¬£4.99 for that matter is a bit of a stretch. While I really admire the concept behind The Stanley Parable, which is what drove me to purchace the game in the first place, I personally found it to be dull and disappointing.
The Stanley Parable has lots of positive (yet, unhelpful) reviews, which ultimately leads anybody to believe that it's a fun game, that is the main purpose of a game, right? Unfortunately for me, the game just didn't live up to the expectations set, so I am relieved that I didn't end up paying full price for it (¬£9.99 in my case), if I had, I'd certainly have felt cheated, let me elaborate.

The game itself is appealing because it is genuinely interesting and refreshingly different, the trailer and the highest rated user reviews don't really give much information away because it genuinely would ruin the experience, but all in all, this is not a game, it is a lecture.
The Stanley Parable attempts to convey a message about game design and the illusion of choice, and while this message is conveyed well through the narration (great voice acting) it is in no way a fun experience. Sure, some of the dialog can be amusing, but that for me is the only positive factor.
There is no real gameplay and there are no real objectives, The Stanley Parable offers nothing more than a few hours of exploration around repetitive and dull scenery, waiting for the next line of dialog to pop up more often than not. I can't speak for everybody, but having to sit and listen for instructions on what to do next is not my idea of a fun experience, and even though the project is very well made and has a good concept behind it, I believe that you would have had the exact same experience just watching a play through of it.

Fans of the game tend to use the argument that if you don't enjoy The Stanley Parable, it's because you don't understand it, which I'm afraid is simply untrue. I understood the messages conveyed and I think the idea and crafting behind the game is clever and very unique, but all in all, I regret spending money on a game that turned out to be an unsatisfying lecture. The reason I buy games is to have a fun experience, and unfortunately I didn't achieve that at all playing this one.

I firmly stand by my suggestion to avoid paying the full asking price for The Stanley Parable, but again, it's all down to choice. If you do feel compelled to buy it regardless of any negative reviews in favour of the (mostly) vague positive reviews, don't expect any actual fun gameplay, because I honestly believe there isn't any to be found here.

Please note that this review is purely my own thoughts and opinions, so I know there will be people that agree with me and certainly others that do not. If you are one of the people who purchased this game and felt that you had spent your money well, then excellent, I'm glad that you enjoyed the experience more than I did.

reviewText: Any individual with even the slightest or most remote interest in video gaming as a medium of artistic expression must categorically play The Stanley Parable within their lifetime. It's, ostensibly, a re-release of the 2011 Half-Life 2 mod of the same name, and is still built on the Source engine and is, more or less, largely the same game but having been thoroughly redesigned in certain key ways, especially its themes and parts of its narrative structure.\n\nThe Stanley Parable (developed by a small indie studio named Galactic Cafe) is, essentially, as its demo states, a game of endings". It's a game that poses some very important questions about the way games currently work - it's a parable (a story which illustrates a lesson)
date: or rather a collection of parables each hidden within another. Each new playthrough represents a new part of the experience
recommended: revealing yet another of the game's many endings
hoursPlayed: each with a different existential or absurdist lesson that build into the game's broader thesis.\n\nIt's also a game of choice
voteText: in that it proposes that ludic notions of "choice" and "free will" are inherently absurd in all games
helpfulPercent: since they don't actually represent any kind of meaningful or significant choice: they're just slightly different parts of the same overall plan that the game designer has laid out before you
votesHelpful: and thus subordinate to his own intentions and choices; and therefore
votesTotal: inconsequential. You're still only just walking that path - in fact
votesFunny: all you ever do in the Stanley Parable is walk; literally. And when you do press the use button (which is for ludic purposes the mouse button
commentsCount: but in the original mod
column16: was the 'E' button)
column17: you hear the unmistakable sound of a key being pressed. And as the intro and several endings exemplify
column18: that is the nature of Stanley's job and ultimately
column19: the nature of his existence and of our experience within the game: pressing buttons
column20: both in-game and out of game.\n\nIt also has a lot to say about endings
column21: and the way choices feed into those endings. By presenting us with a closed environment with very minimal and sparse mechanics
column22: The Stanley Parable is able to present us with an environment so sparse and so limited that the "choices" we are offered seem that much more significant and that much more abundant; and the same goes for its endings. But as much as the choices themselves mean nothing
column23: they also lead the player into the aforementioned endings. No ending has finality
column24: and no ending presents a perfect victory for Stanley or the player. In fact
column25: in almost all the endings the respective thematic conflict between Stanley and the Narrator remains entirely open
column26: but no ending feeds into another in any capacity
column27: underlining the lack of meaning the notion of multiple endings in games can offer. Games teach the player that anything but a perfect win-state is a failure
column28: and that further playthroughs can objectively improve the conclusion of the story
column29: be it through moral superiority or mechanical perfection. The Stanley Parable
column31: gives us subjective endings which can be interpreted freely which all invariably lead into a restart of the game. As the game itself states: "the end is never the end is never the end is never the end is never LOADING".\n\nIn the process
column32: certain themes and concepts will be left underdeveloped; but isn't this the point of the game? Asking questions that only subsequent explorations of the game by way of critical commentary or subsequent works in the same vein (perhaps by Galactic Cafe
column33: or other designers) will be able to answer? Leaving its own ideas open to interpretation and exploration? I certainly think so. And so
column34: it's definitely worth experiencing for yourself. Set your prejudices regarding "walking simulators" or "ungames" aside and walk into The Stanley Parable without any expectations but those the game designer creates for himself and for his own vision."

reviewText:
Whether or not you feel you have gained anything from the Stanley Parable will depend on how much you value a minor metaphorical critique on ‚Äògaming choices‚Äô and if so, whether or not that is worth it in direct relation to the amount you spent. In a nutshell, this ‚Äògame‚Äô is essentially an attempt by you, Stanley, to discover what has happened to your co-workers and bosses, all of whom have completely disappeared.

That‚Äôs the game in its entirety on a superficial level without giving away any spoilers. The underlying message is regarding the choice, or the illusion of choice, that modern video games allude to offer. The developers seem to be responding to games such as Mass Effect, that suggest they offer the gamer real choice in the outcome of the narrative yet in reality the gamer only has a couple of options dressed up in different clothing. There is a clear critique here regarding the nature of ‚Äòchoice‚Äô in the video game industry and while it is welcomed change for video games to include a metaphorical message (beyond the simplistic), these messages and critiques should not exist in a vacuum, devoid of any gameplay. The point being that, there is a thought provoking message here, but this is not a game.

Stripped down, the Stanley Parable is a game of ‚Äòwalk and listen‚Äô. Yes there are some interesting points mentioned by the narrator relating to conscious decision making, but this same message could have been offered through or alongside gameplay features that stretched beyond walking around a corridor. Quite simply, this is a lecture, a chore of a lecture that unfortunately lasts for 2-3 hours before you realise you could have just read the same underlying message in a free online article in about 10 minutes without being subjected to this gaming con artistry.

Clearly there is a sense that the Stanley Parable is offering some ‚Äòhigh art‚Äô by not including actual gameplay, or that this ‚Äògenius indie title‚Äô will have your head scratching. There is a suggestion that if you ‚Äòdon‚Äôt get‚Äô intelligent games that you won‚Äôt appreciate the Stanley Parable, that you can‚Äôt grasp its deeper message. Well, that is quite frankly a gross lie and yet a master stroke in marketing. People are desperately scrabbling to offer rave reviews of this new form of game, eager to show they are not cut from the COD cloth of gaming, that they can enjoy this intellectual critique. Do not be fooled. This is a totally unsatisfactory experience especially considering the price charged.

Do you want a thought provoking experience about the intricacies of the mind and the illusion of choice? Read a book. This is just pseudo-philosophical gaming at its very worst, conning the masses into feeling like an intellectual giant for a couple hours at the small price of being tricked by the illusion of gameplay. Who‚Äôs more of a sucker in this scenario, Stanley? Or us?

'The game will end, the game will never end'. Sold to us as an interesting game of uncertainty. Well, there is at least one certainty about the Stanley Parable; you will never see the cash you spent again.

As always comments are welcomed and I will try to get back to you as soon as possible.

reviewText:
It's good for what it's trying to do. To be honest, though, I sometimes think I should've spent my money on something else. Since there isn't an option to classify you're review as mixed, since there were parts I liked about the game, I'm just labeling it as negative (not because I completely hated it).

The Narrator is a really funny character and I laughed at a lot of his reactions. However, that's all I really found enjoyable. It's not that I didn't like everything else, it's just there didn't seem to be much else to do.

You get different endings depending on your choices, but after playing it over and over for a while I already got most of the obvious (as in easy to obtain") endings and was just running in to them again and again multiple times. I know there's more complex things you can do to get different endings
recommended: but it made me think I could've just easily looked them up on YouTube instead of spending $15. I was playing a game with no real challenge to prevent me from getting to those endings.\n\nI understand that it's supposed to be more an experience then just a game
hoursPlayed: but I personally didn't find it that philosophical with it's message and would've been better off getting an actual game on Steam. I'd have probably enjoyed this more if it was either for free or at a lower price. I don't think it's worth $15
voteText: you'd be better off spending that money on Shovel Knight."

reviewText:
AUDIONarratedVISUALSimpleDIFFICULTYN/AVIBECuriousCRAVINGMental Chewing GumON SALEInfrequent
PROS: The exploration in Stanley Parable needs no introduction or enticement. Narration is excellent, both humorous and thought-provoking. Stanley Parable creates boundaries for the sole purpose of breaking them.

CONS: Those staunchly against walking simulators should check further into the games content before purchase. The game had a few unexpected, personally-upsetting moments. A few of the achievements are very gimmicky and hard to obtain.

WORTH: It's probably the best of its kind, but that can hold little value to a person disinterested in this sort of philosophical walking sim style game. This game's worth is definitely dependent on what you like, but it doesn't hurt to know that it sees an occasional sale every other month.

OVERALL: You know when you're willingly spending a couple hours exploring an empty office, the creators have managed to do something pretty awesome.

SCORE:9/10

Stanley Parable I think its a game about wasted youth. The short story is greatly represented by a narrator that follows every move you make. Now if you think that's cool try Bastion too :P

Now there is an achievement called [Go Outside] Don't play The Stanley Parable for five years." which I ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ed up... set my clock to 2021 and wrongly earned it without thinking decently.
After 10 seconds .. I felt reallly bad. It was a mistake. I know that might sounds stupid but developers maybe had it for a reason. Luckily there is a command I found on steam discussions* that resets all 10-achievements to 0 and you must earn 'em again; a small price to pay.

Moral: Don't rush things

reviewText:
EVEN IF YOU'VE BOUGHT THIS GAME, PLAY THE DEMO! The demo is entirely original  content, and is easily as good as the main game.

About the game:

With only about 3 hours worth of content and minimal replay value, it's hard to justify the purchase price. Pick it up if it goes on sale, though...

Since the store page isn't very helpful, here's what the game is about. It's an exploration game in the same vein as Dear Esther or 30 Flights of Loving. You wander around looking at things and the environment is only minimally interactive. An extremely clever and witty narrator tells your story as you wander through the environment.

Gameplay uses FPS controls and there are few cutscenes to interrupt the immersion, but you will often find yourself trapped in a small area waiting for something. This is less annoying in The Stanley Parable than it is in other games since listening to the narration is basically the whole point of the game.

The plot moves along a lot like a choose-your-own-adventure. You'll be repeatedly sent back to the beginning of the game and need to repeat one of a few choices that select which ending you get. There aren't a lot of choices to make and only about 10 endings, but there are some random elements to the game and some of the endings have an effect on your next restart, so there is enough variety to keep the beginning of the game interesting even though you'll see it many times.

The plot is extremely witty, clever, and well narrated. The dialogue is easily as good as Portal II, even if the gameplay is rather bland. I liked it and I'm glad I played it, even though I feel I overpaid for it at $12.

I decided not to follow the narrator's instructions when I first joined the game. It took me nearly an hour to realise that I was supposed to follow what he says. When I finally realised what to do, the game had ended.

10/10 would get lost again.

reviewText:
After playing the brilliant, but very short, original Half Life 2 mod, I was very eager to play this when it was announced that they were making a full game.

With funny, clever and witty humor from the narrator, who is simply brilliant, this game was highly enjoyable from the start to its err....ending(s). My only disappointment really was that it's a bit on the short side.

So overall, I strongly recommend this game to anybody. :-)
voteText: 27 of 38 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Fantastic game, one that I found intriguing, funny, creepy, enlighting and hauting at the same time. Stanley's Parable is a game-shaped narrative experiment about game design tropes among other things. I don't want to say more but trust me, like or not, this is something you should play, even if it just for a little bit. Also, In an age with some many great indie game feature strong quirky narration, Stanley's narrator still stands out in the crowd. I could write a lot about Stanley Parable, but I don't have to because it has probably the best demo I've ever seen for a game, a demo that showcases the spirit and mechanics of the game but it's completely unique. Download it, and if you find it intriguing enough, then by all means, buy and play the real game.
voteText: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
So this is going to be another spoiler-free super-secretive ultra-vague review of The Stanley Parable.

Is the game worth getting? Yes.
Is it as mysterious and thought provoking as it is supposed to be? Yes, not in a bad way either.
I do have to say visually the game was more impressive than I expected, it uses Source pretty well.
The narration is beautiful, but of course that's obvious.
The game works. It really does. It's a pretty far-reaching concept and yet it's a success.

Hell, it even manages to use the loading screen as a plot device.

Bottom line, if you love games, you'll most likely love The Stanley Parable. Is it worth the pretty high asking price? Absolutely.

reviewText:
Way too overpriced for what you get !

Look at all the top positive reviews. Very few have a playtime longer than 3-4 hours, because that's really all you can stretch out of it.     One of the achievements requires running the game up to 24 hours in a single setting (although you can trick the game by editing your BIOS)  My own review would only show about 2 hours of actual gameplay. The rest, was idling for the achievement. Almost every review that shows a play time over 24 hours is misleading if you think they actually got that much time and attention out of it. You can literally see and pick apart everything in the game in just a few hours, especially if you are particularly clever.  I have 8 friends who currently own this, i combined all of their total play times. approx. 16 hours combined. Add in the actual 2 hours I was playing, and we're sittin at 18 hours total. Its not a tremendous value.

I bought it at a 75 percent off sale, and I still feel they were asking too much.  Its just a source mod with some clever writing. I wished there was more game here, because there's nothing wrong with what you get ! The game" and the experience it provides is great!  but the price
date: oh lord. that price.\nBeing such a high priced game and having all the positive reviews simultaneously
recommended: i expected a lot more.\n\nIf this was $3.75 or less (what i paid) I would change my review to positive. For 14.99
hoursPlayed: you could get so much more than what this will offer you."

reviewText:
A Paladin's Steam Review: The Stanley Parable. That Game You've Heard Of.Genre: 1st Person Self Exploration.
Developed & Published by: Galactic Cafe
Platform: Windows, Mac and Linux
Business Model: Base Game
Copy Purchased by Myself Overall Gameplay Thoughts
Is Stanley Parable a game? Are you a real person? Ok, you've probably gotten sick of hearing this joke when it comes to reviews about the Stanley Parable, so I'll knock it off. But cmon, I had to have a little fun. Yea, that joke was old even when I originally posted this review. So, time to put a bit of strikethrough it and put some actual effort into talking about the game itself. You play as Stanley, an office worker that wants something more out of life. Or maybe he doesn't. The game mechanics are simple: you walk through doors, hallways and rooms while listening to an excellent British accent describing what you are or aren't doing. Or going on a rambling about some unrelated happening. Or maybe its incredibly related and you don't realize it. Sometimes you'll push buttons, open doors or fall to your death. But really, those actions that you perform aren't what matter most. It's what you take away from the experience that matters. You'll be replaying the levels over and over again as different actions can cause different little stories" to play themselves out. It's a pretty passive experience though as you can't really do anything other than choose minor actions at certain times.

This could have easily been a game stuck up on itself but it's clear that the developers want us to consider what it is to live this life and to play videogames. How we interact and deal with videogames on a regular basis. There's quite a bit more under the surface than even I gave it credit for after I finished playing it and watched some other people talk about it.

PC Settings
The game comes with more PC settings than you could possibly ever want or need for a game like TSP. Resolutions
recommended: AA/Shader/Effect/Texture detail controls and much more. Everything is here
hoursPlayed:
even support for high framerates. The game is very stable from all that I can tell and have heard. There is nothing missing that I can think you would need.

Final Thoughts
This is a title where I don't think it matters what I think. I think it's a title you need to explore for yourself and take away from it what you will. It is essentially a walking simulator
voteText: I won't deny that. And the player interactivity is minimal at best. But
helpfulPercent: I think its worth checking out. Take the time to appreciate what's being said and shown to you.\n\nRead this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade.[kingisaaclinksr.com]"
votesTotal: true

reviewText:
Pros+ Simple control's. W,S,A,D as in any game. And responisve at the same time.
+ Polished around the corner. Well designed room's and interiors .i haven't experienced bug's.
+ Fine,fine graphic's for it's genre. Not something astounding as the witcher 3 or crysis as it wasn't mean't to be like that.
+ Great sound-track. and over all crisp sound's.
+ A brilliant,interesting,mind bobling and really inovative story. With multiple consequences.
+ Very well voice acted narration from multiple people.
+ A very well designed menu and not seen elseware menu aswell responsive.

Cons- A bit long load time's.
- Very short roughly about more than 3 hour's if you play through all the endings.
- Asking price is a bit to much as there's not much there. A far better price would be to charge $9.99 dollar's.

Worth it?Well as you can see it's really small and not something you would get for value from a $14.99 dollar game, but it's really well on what it does it's mostly perfectly just not much content for the asking price as it is.if you have many money to blow then just buy it you will love it but if you have a limited budget i say get it on sale.

I'm aware i only have 1" hour's of playtime in the game as i have not yet finshed all the ending's. But let me tell you all this playtime was enough for me to judge it as the game is actually (short) i might add.

reviewText: After Stanley realizes that the usual day in his office is quiet...quiet, he stands up from his desk and choose to search for his co-workers....or not. Since here begins the branching story of The Stanley Parable".\n\nTSP is more or less an interactive adventure
date: a simpler version of the 80's game "Alter Ego" if you will. This goes along pretty well especially due the witty nature of the Narrator
recommended: which guides you through the game and choices.\n\nIt's overall cleverly written and dances between the ‚ÄúIt's oh so random‚Äù and ‚Äú2deep4you‚Äù themes so well
hoursPlayed:
that you willingly fill the gaps and contradictions with your own meaning. This is one of the main reasons I believe that gamers and critics love it so much.

What I liked:
+: Cleverly written.
+: The Narrator (I'm a sucker for british english anyway).
+: Fitting ambient sounds and music.
+: Includes some not very obvious (or I wouldnt had thought of that) routes which leads to other "endings".

What I didn't like:
-: It's short.
-: The pricing imho is way to high. Yeah

reviewText:
‚ÄùNothing that is expressed is obscene. What is obscene is what is hidden.‚Äù -Nagisa Oshima***Before beginning, I would like to give a special thanks to my fianc√© for proofing this review for me, as well as to wish her an early Happy Anniversary. Thank you for giving me the five most wonderful years of my life.
What some consider to be an Indie gem while others plea confusion as to the course of this title, The Stanley Parable is a game about choice and consequence, with moderately brief journeys being the focus of play. The player takes control of Stanley, an office worker whose position entails the pressing of buttons throughout the day; the operation of these simple devices is his sole function, until one bizarre day, all of his coworkers vanish. From here Stanley leaves his office unprompted in search of some answers. I will do my best to refrain from writing this review in the identical joking tone of most writings, though the comedy in this title is infectious.
Here are just a few reasons to give this memorably fantastic game a try:

Atmosphere - This title progresses through Stanley‚Äôs well-crafted office space as the player maneuvers through the expected rooms and hallways that you would foresee composing a business department. I do not wish to spoil much about the broom closet, cargo lift, mind control facility, or other sections of The Stanley Parable‚Äôs branching story for the sake of having you experience them for yourself.

Gameplay - As stated in the introduction, players assume the role of Stanley from a first person perspective as he explores his abandoned office spaces, through multiple unique rooms and themes in order to discover the ‚Äòfinale‚Äô for the tale. The controls are simple, with the W, A, S, and D keys acting as movement commands; the Control key assuming the crouched position; and the LMB allowing the player to interact with various objects within the environment. There are both hidden and pronounced articles within the environment that can be toggled to alter story paths-covered in the coming section.

Writing - As unambiguous as this game appears to be, this story-rich satire is far from any other market experience. The Stanley Parable performs as expected, with the players unraveling new beginnings and ends while probing for secluded secrets. Between these points of interest, the brilliant Kevan Brighting voices each interaction-or lack there-of-to entail a sense of accomplishment for the player, in the stead of simply stalling in a daft room until prompted otherwise. This commentary is extremely witty, and displays each critical action Stanley makes. In a sense, this is more of a powerful placebo to gaming: it takes the form of what you expect any game would yet lacks just the right amount of properties, toning it a simulation.

TL:DR - As with the quote above, The Stanley Parable is an obscure game which presents the perfect amount of subtly in its processes. There can never be a proper review for The Stanley Parable due to how absurdly miraculous it is, yet every review written about it is the perfect review since it is that of individuality, such as with this title; the only true way to understand this title is to simply play it for yourself. As much as I would love to write on and on about this title, no words can do it justice, as it is difficult to pinpoint every exceptional portion of this work. I highly recommend this title to those who enjoy titles depicting choice and consequence, as well as narratives. Thanks for reading.

Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews.

reviewText:
Right now, there is nothing about The Stanley Parable that I don't hate.

There are games built around a cohesive story with relatable characters, a satisfying dramatic arc and a worthwhile conclusion. This is not one of those games. The Stanley Parable is confusing and all-over-the-place, the main characters are inconsistent, sometimes depressingly shallow, other times infuriatingly opaque. The story spits on the ideals of internal logic.

If a video game makes you want to stop playing video games, what does that say about it?

The Stanley Parable dragged me into its tangled mass of content without much of a warning. During most of my time playing it, I had at best a vague idea of what was going on. And although it tried everything in its power to defeat me (at one point it was literally begging me to stop playing), I pressed on.

The game is ruthless in its mission of deconstructing the concepts of video game narration. It draws back the curtain and exposes the man who pulls the strings. Or pushes the buttons, as it were. Am I able to simply go back to normal games with normal stories, pretend I didn't gaze into the abyss? I can only hope.

I think I've come reasonably close to hearing everything that The Stanley Parable has to tell. Its attention to detail is impressive, the love and skill that went into it easily apparent. At times I felt like Sherlock Holmes, with my personal Moriarty always one tantalizing step ahead. Other times I felt a sense of true companionship when my friend and I forged ahead towards destiny. Yet other times I was confronted with a sadistic psychopath, a gentle father figure, or a petty, passive-agressive bystander.

The Stanley Parable raises more questions than it answers. Fortunately they are the right kind of questions, the ones that keep you questioning yourself and the world around you rather than frustrate and paralyze you. I'm still relishing the afterglow, so my opinion may shift slightly when I've made more progress processing my experiences.

Right now though, there is nothing about The Stanley Parable that I don't love.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is one of the most remarkable games I've ever played.

It is a game about games. It's about the relationship between the player and the game and the interactivity that makes this medium unique.

That's about as much as I can say about The Stanley Parable without giving anything away. There are no mechanics bound to your keyboard and mouse beyond move, look, open doors and push buttons. The central mechanic of the game is your choice and your perception of the game, incarnated as the Narrator.

The game is essentially a choose your own adventure book, elevated to become something truly special by excellent writing, one of the endings features a profound paradox, and phenomenal delivery by the Narrator.

The Stanley Parable is extremely clever, amusing and thought-provoking. An absolute must-buy, though I would recommend playing the demo first.

<3

reviewText:
Product received for free

The Stanley Parable is an experimental narrative-driven first person game. It is an exploration of choice, freedom, storytelling and reality, all examined through the lens of what it means to play a video game.

- You will make a choice that does not matter

- You will follow a story that has no end

- You will play a game you cannot win

...it's actually best if you don't know anything about it before you play it...

The HD Remix of The Stanley Parable is a remodeled, remastered version of this unique title.

I think this is not even a game, but in life someone told us to give us advice, and someone wants to scourge us, he brings a very deep meaning. 10/10

reviewText:
There isnt really any other game quite like this one. It's an adventure that changes with each playthrough based on the decisions you make. You are Stanley and you start out in your stale office, in your stale job, in your stale life....or do you? Perhaps your life is amazing, sad, depressed, happy...whatever. The choice is yours.

The gameplay is seamless. Perfect controls for the game. The graphics are also top notch. It actually looks like the Unity engine a bit, but if it was, the developer maximized what he got out of it. Some of the puzzles can be challenging, and deception factors in to some aspects of this game as well.

The narration however is really where this game is at. There are only two other games that I can think of that rivals this one in that regard (Battleblock Theater, Bastion), although their styles couldnt be more different.

I have seen something like 18 different endings with this game. Not sure how many there really are, but there are a lot, and so as you can expect, there is a ton of replay value with this game.

The developer also had some fun with the achievements. One of them is to play all day (24 hours) on a Tuesday, lol. One is to play, and then play again a year later. Etc....

This game is an easy 10/10. It is perfect for what it is trying to be, doesnt force anything, and allows itself to be whatever you want it to be.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable does NOT contain the following:

Enemies
Guns
Enemies with guns
Magic
Health bars
Conversation trees
Skill trees
Dubstep
Quick Time Events
Puzzles
Jumping
Feet
Microtransactions
DLC

What you do get in exchange for all of this is roleplaying as a delusional office worker who mostly goes against the voice in his head. Also, some of the doors close behind you which obviously means that you're actually being followed by a ghost or someone invisible the entire time.

11/10 would be spooked again

reviewText: If BioShock was a lesson in player agency, The Stanley Parable would be the whole course. The Stanley Parable encourages players to defy its one simple rule -- follow the directions. Your refusal to play along results in some of the most hilarious moments in gaming. But beyond the finely tuned humor is a thought-provoking, memorable game that will stick with you long after you walk by the credits. This is an absolute must-play.

it looks like you're just wandering around an office in an FPS where you can't shoot or jump.

And that's true.

But it's not a fair assessment.  The Stanley Parable is -- to employ an outdated and well-trodden expression -- "like a Choose Your Own Adventure on crack".

It's a game about choice.  Your coworkers have vanished
voteText:
and you are tasked with finding out why.

Will you bother to discover where they went?  Or maybe you'll forge your own path.  But what consequences could there be for straying from the story?  What if compliance was actually...in your best interest?  Will you ever find the myriad secrets and endings tucked away?  Will you even go so far as to cheat to find them?!  (Seriously?!)

The Stanley Parable has been a deeply memorable experience. It's a haunting

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is a biting, witty and satirical take on the current state of video-games. Their design and interaction mechanics, how they function to entice your progress (or impede) through the game's plot and enviornment.

Throughout the game, there is a narrator who guides you through your curated experience, in certain points of conflict or 'choice' he tries to coerce you down the 'right' path. Whether you follow this disembodied voice or no is left up-to you but Galactic Cafe accepts a 'players' right of impositing their own 'choicesi/i]' in the game.

The Parable has a minimalist soundtrack and soundscape which seek to complement the rather barren and sterile look of the game environment and the feeling of disconnect with the same.

Overall The Stanley Parable is a wonderful look at how everything is right and wrong with the way games are presented to their audience, gamers and how we are stimulated to be kept in this circle.

Also, you cannot jump and this game has an ADVENTURE LINE. You got to purchase the game just so you can follow that, YES! YES! You must.

reviewText:
This game starts as a walking-simulator in an office listening to a beautiful voice. The narrator wants to guide the player, and then starts to complain when the latter does not follow the rules. A love-hate relationship grows between the player and the narrator.
The experience seems short but actually there are tons of branching paths (sometimes leading to different places and concepts), and the deeper themes of the game start to unravel. Choice and free will, a meta commentary on videogame narration and player agency, and so on.

Very meta, very funny, each playthrough is short but sweet and got me excited to try new things and see how the narrator would react.
voteText: 10 of 13 people (77%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had high expecations for this game, but I was still suprised about how good it actually is.
This is the closest you'll get to having a real choice in video games. Multiple endings and converations with several answers are merely an illusion of having a free will.
Even the biggest roleplaying games feel like being on a railcar that drives you through a storyline in comparison with The Stanley Parable.
The duration of a single playthrough is short, but everytime you start anew, everything can and will be different. Even choosing the same path over and over again, will be different from the first, second and even third time you did.
I highly recommend playing it, to give yourself the chance to see what a truly interactive game can be -- and not just by the watered-down definition the medium uses.

reviewText:
I'm back with another handy-dandy review. There's not much I can say about this game without spoiling things for you. Because of this, all I can say is: this game is amazing. I can't tell you why because that would ruin it. Don't look it up online. Just buy it and play it blindly for the best experience. Trust me, it's worth it. The only thing I will say is that there are several endings, so be sure to play through the game like 5 to 10 times (It's worth it).

Although I can't talk about things that are in the game, I can give you some tips to improve your experience.

HELPFUL TIPS:

DO NOT SKIP THE INTRO CUT SCENE

Just don't.

LISTEN TO THE NARRATOR

You don't have to do what he says, but listen to what he has to say.

GET THE DOOR 430 ACHIEVEMENT

(After playing through the game a time or two)


That's about it. Buy. Play. Enjoy. If you liked the review, please let me know by hitting the thumbs up button below. And as always, Happy Gaming!

See my other reviews at http://steamcommunity.com/id/flinchmeister/recommended/

reviewText:
If the left door is the right door and the right door is the right door then everything is normal. Right?

Are you normal? Are you sane? Are you in control?

Really?

8

Could you burn a baby if you had to? Is 2+6=fish correct? Can you not press a key. Can you not answer a phone. What if your life depended on it?

Are you confused?  Maybe you should play the demo. You shouldn't take my word for it, I may be trying to make you choose.  Even if the choice you make is not the right choice.

Will you know?

Perhaps the choice you make will be the right choice, it must be. It couldn't possibly be the wrong choice because it was the choice you made. Right?

The Stanley Parable. It's your choice. Perhaps.

reviewText:
One of the most clever, thought-provoking deconstruction of common video game narratives and tropes in recent years. This is not a typical video game in the most common sense. Instead, it is an effective vehicle for some of the most important subjects pertaining to video games and their narrative. Where Dear Esther failed by wasting the video game medium for its narrative, The Stanley Parable succeeded by making full use of video game mechanics, and then subverts them in a humourous, and yet elegant way.

This game is designed to be played several times, and the real value of this game is to see what happens when you stray from the narrative that the game sets the player out to follow.

I will not discuss the specifics of this game, as doing so will ruin the sense of discovery so vital to keeping the experience effective, Instead, I will tell you to go pick it up and experience it, several times. You will not regret it.

reviewText:
Giving this game a thrumb up is as hard as giving it a thrumb down.
The Stanley Parable is a WITTY game.

Pros:
+ Multiple Endings
+ Good immersive deriving from interactions with the Narrator
+ Impressive combination of scene and narration
+ Countless Easter Eggs
+

Cons:
- Short contents
- Pseudo-intelletual plot
-

In the game, the game-makers show us an interesting story with their inspirational thinking through the endless loop of our protagnist, Stanley's fate. It trys to discuss the probabilities that derive from obedience and rebellion, and to achieve a high-level of interaction between players and the game. I cannot allege it is successful, but this attempt is praisable.

Various endings is an attraction of the game. Among those endings, my favoriate one is the 'Crazy Ending', which will be achieved by walking down the stairs instead of up. The final narration is so good that it makes me feel I am Stanley, and being assisted by repetitive rooms, description of thinking and the style of stream-of-consciousness, it gives players an intense atomsphere and great immersive. Every ending is so distictive and interesting that can inspire players to try every choice over and over again. Under those circunstances, I think, it is as a metapher, instead of as a simple character, that should Stanley be defined.

The narrator is the most important role in the game. It is he who continuously pushs the story forward and guides Stanley into different endings. He can be regarded as a highlight and also a drawback of the game. His words and tone contribute to game's style and atmosphere, but also undermine it's reality. If most of the narration can be replaced by text and make it focus on pushing the climax(just like what he does in the Crazy Ending), it would be more splendid.

Except those advantages, this game is quite boring. Although it seems like players are exploring the game, but they not. All they can do is just walk along the routes that pre-designed by game-makers, and repetitive narration helps me comfirm it. Simply, throughout the game what players play is to choose 'left or right?'. It does provide some interesting things, but the gameplay and replaybility are poor. But you can regarded it as a voiced novel.

Another drawback is that the game is so short that players can beat it within 10 mins. Although it contains multiple endings and the plot will be changed just result from slight changes in choices‚Äî‚Äîit is still too short ‚Üí_‚Üí. $15 is too much, so I strongly suggest anyone who wants to try this game keep waiting for this game apparing in bundles.

How to define this game? Or, more prudentlyÔºåshould it be defined as a game?
Without a doubt it is a good experiment. Yet, compared with novels and movies of the same type, The Stanley Parable seems still primitive.

reviewText:
Prepare for spoilers. Normally I don't spoil, but it's mighty hard with this one.

To enjoy The Stanley Parable, it takes a peculiar type of person. Or types of persons. There is no 'action' to speak of in this game. No guns to shoot and, debatably, not even a failure condition. (even if you CAN die...)

I've been troubled in finding the best way to describe this game. People have called it a mind‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, something that messes with your logic. But from the moment I defied the narrator, I never felt like that. I didn't feel like I was being tossed around with. I felt like I was in a thought experiment. A thought experiment that got out of hand and resulted in other thought experiments, until it had evolved into a narrative in how I'm seemingly breaking the purpose of these by simply not cooperating.

What I've concluded is that The Stanley Parable is a narrative genius. A statement on multiple facets. For example, the question can be asked how the power of the narrator compares to that of a hypothetical God? And what if the subjects in the universe the narrator and/or hypothetical god are ruling, become sentient?

But that's not the only question that can surface. Your question could be how defiant can I be and not die? What if death is part of the pathway and continuing forward will actually result in a different outcome based on the fact that I died?"
Yes
date:
that seems like a very long and convoluted question...

But that's what this game does. It makes you question the reality it resides in. The non-eucledian level design (Google it) means that any progress is progress permitted to you by the narrator. But then you reach a point where even the narrator questions their own power and choices.

Or you could have taken such choices that angered the narrator so much that he instead turned confrontational and made you face the fact that

reviewText:
This game is great. I would say almost as brilliant as Portal. Just try it, you'll like it if you like Portal.

Edit:

I was pondering what to add to this review, but I can't. The story is self-explanatory enough (and I do not want to spoil it, that is half the fun), and the mechanics is just brilliant. I would and I will just say this: the game itself is amazing, but the best part is the thought behind such a concept, and will ask you some questions that you will never think of when you are playing other games.

If you want another CoD / HL2 shooty-blasty-killing FPS variant, this is not the game that you want, BUT...if you want to play a thought-driven experimental with will-crafted humor like Portal, you would enjoy this game as much as I did, and remember this experience for a long time.

As for the price itself, I almost got every content within the eight hours that I played, so the original price is not that good compare to other games that can let you be enjoyable for hours and hours for 15 bucks (or less). But I think the price is well worth-it if you got it on sale (I got it for 40% off and I'm satisfied for the content at the price).

I would strongly-suggested that you do not read any reviews that contains spoilers, any videos that has gameplay footage on it, and even the trailers that posted on this very page, just experience it (demo or the full game) and enjoy, employee 427.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is an interactive story, set inside an abandoned office.

You are Stanley, right? You follow a story, or were you making one?  Well, It doesn't matter, whoever you're or whatever the choices you make, you'll be wondering trough several of the consequences of your actions, getting to know more and to ask for more with every step you make. And I'll be honest, it was hell of a fun.

My only complain would be its length, I mean, there's literally an achievement for speed running the game in less than 5 minutes, and all the different endings can be achieved in about 4 hours, except for one that takes 4 hours alone (...)

reviewText:
6.5/10

Pros:
-The sheer amount of endings and different outcomes is phenomenal
-The narrator is one of the best when it comes to video games
-Hilarious, lots of jokes, ranging from pop culture, to geek culture
-Quirky achievements

Cons:
-The endings can all be found extremely quickly, resulting in a short game
-Not much added or changed from the original (free) mod
-Although the achievements are interesting, they will leave a bad taste in the mouth of any hunters out there
-Repetitiveness of certain scenarios can be annoying to some

Recommeneded Purchase Price: <$7

reviewText:
I really enjoyed 'The Stanley Parable', I enjoyed it the same way some obessive about movies enjoys an movie critique and other examples that I can't honestly think of right now.

Does the fact that I enjoyed this game, and I mean I enjoyed it a lot actually makes this game a good game though? ( I hope no one gets man, since the whole point of the game is to get people to think and ask questions). As a whole, I don't honestly think so. As a game I think 'The Stanley Parable' is pretty mediocre in terms of its mechanics and aesthetics. Its narrator and script are top notch though and really carry the game ensuring that its tone and mood are always spot on. As a whole, I think people should play this game, its the equivilent to visiting an art museam in my opinion, just a bit more engaging.

A more robust review of the game can be found on my blog over here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/03/the-stanley-parable.html.

reviewText:
I can't even call The Stanley Parable as a 'game', which is so far from being something bad, it is more like an 'experience', some other kind of gaming from a very different and weird perspective (I'm having a hard time defining that..), a type of perspective which can for example make adults who are purely against gaming in one way or another, actually enjoy playing it (Except the ones who'll turn the game off in the main menu.). Not sure if it makes sense.

Well, whatever. I don't know if it is an experience which everybody would enjoy. I also don't know if it justifies its full price (I got it from a sale anyways.) or not. What I do know is that, I wish I could forget all I know about The Stanley Parable, and play it once again.

reviewText: Sarcastic, funny, and very metaphysical, The Stanley Parable is existentialism the video game. There are no challanges or puzzles in this game. All you have are your choices, the consequences of those choices, and that nagging feeling that your not actually making any choices at all. Are you really in control of anything you do, or is every decision you make just in reaction to what someone told you to do or not do? Play the stanley Parable and find out

reviewText:
The very first thing that should be mentioned about the Stanley Parable is that it is short. Very short. This is not to say the game is not worth getting, quite the contrary. However, waiting for a good sale is probably the most prudent course of action given the length of the game.

In a way the Stanley Parable is like a Choose Your Own Adventure book. While you play as Stanley, the narrator will tell the story of Stanley and which actions the narrator wishes you to follow. However, there are multiple points where you can choose to follow the narrator or not. When choosing to follow the narrator, it is possible to complete the game in a little over four minutes, but the fun is in exploring all of the various paths and seeing the various endings to the game. The narration is done wonderfully, and as the narrator becomes frustrated with your choices, the game can become rather comical.

The game is an exporation in story telling, and while simple, it is very well done.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: DO. NOT. SUBMIT.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: While Antichamber uses philosophical wisecracking as mere specific hints for solving puzzles and Dear Esther doesn't really deserve to be called an interactive story, playing The Stanley Parable is like going on a spiritual journey. There's a massive feedback effect, making you reflect about your own life. The way it messes with your head I could compare to some of the experiences I had on ayahuasca... how it first tries to confuse you so that you begin to get your narrow rational mind out of the way and open yourself to the big questions. The fact that this 'game' (it's definitely a game if you consider life one, too) has no real end further supports that training character, not unlike the Dao De Jing that you can keep reading again and again and gain new insights every time. While a desire for 'completing' it might eventually get the best of you and make you consult guides, you're definitely not meant to know all there is in this game. It is part of the experience to not have the full view on everything.\nBig themes in The Stanley Parable are the idea of free will and personal responsibility for your decisions, as well as the purpose of life, the challenges we face, destiny and the nature of reality. ... Yeap, this is a vast little game.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I love this game, the narration is amazing and the game is great, but it is not long enough nor is there enough events you can play with. I recommend the game, but I do not think it is worth it's price.
