reviewText: This is a game about a man named Stanley. It is a very strange game with alot of narration and odd humor. And yet, despite its extremely short length, it is worth checking out due to its uniqueness and bizarre storyline.\n\nPlay it for insanity's sake and obnoxious achievements. Woohoo!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is one of those games that you really have to like in order to play properly. Otherwise, it's going to feel like a complete waste of time, totally pointless, maybe even offensively boring. The Stanley Parable is a metaphysical experience that begins right after the studio logo loading screen. The main menu itself is already the first step into a hilarious spiral of deconstructive video game analysis.

I really can't say much about the game itself without spoiling anything, and you really REALLY need to play this game without any prior knowledge of what it's about.

All you need to know is: I recommend this game.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: The Stanley Parable is impossible to truly describe. At its most tame, it's an incredible psychological experience that will stay with you for the rest of your life. It has an outstanding blend of humor and seriousness, wrapped in the type of weirdness you can only find in games like EarthBound or Katamari Damacy. It pokes a lot of fun at various video game tropes, sometimes subtly, sometimes flamboyantly. It makes the player think about their life and the validity and consequences of choice and free will. And it does all this while maintaining a simple but intelligent gameplay experience. So the real question is not what The Stanley Parable has to offer, but rather what you are willing to obtain from it.

reviewText:
Every once in a while, it's nice to come across a game that you weren't expecting, the kind of game that creeps up on you and then stays with you long after you've finished playing.  The Stanley Parable was originally developed as a Source engine mod back in 2010. Its creator Davey Wreden said that he set out to discover something about video games that hadn't been explored yet. More specifically, what would happen if you could disobey their rules.

The game tells the story of Stanley, an average man who finds solace in his simple mundane office job. However on one particular day it appears that all his co-workers have suddenly disappeared. Guided by the narrator, Stanley must step out of the safety of his little cubical and begin his adventure to find out what exactly is going on.

At first glance it might seem easy to categorise this as another artsy walk 'em up" in the vein of something like Dear Esther or Proteus. It has a simple setting
recommended: not much to interact with and of course no jump or weapons
hoursPlayed: so what exactly do you do in The Stanley Parable? Well
voteText: essentially you make decisions. This is because the driving force behind the game is that of "choice". You decide HOW you play the game
helpfulPercent: and the game responds accordingly. And these decisions may appear simple
votesHelpful: left or right? Over there? Over here? Touch that?\n\nMeanwhile you're guided by the soothing sound of 'the narrator' voiced brilliantly by British voice actor Kevan Brighting! The narrator attempts to lead you to successfully complete the game by advising you which path to take as well as narrating the inner monologue of the troubled protagonist Stanley. And it's through this narration that the game achieves a level of hysterical self awareness and brilliant charm very similar to the Portal series. This dynamic narration will react to the decisions you make
votesTotal: often breaking the fourth wall to talk to you directly. And should you decide not to listen to these directions and "disobey" the resulting dialogue and consequences can easily spiral out of control into the strange and surreal.\n\nBut to say anymore would no doubt ruin your experience of The Stanley Parable as no two play throughs are really the same. And multiple play throughs are inevitable in a game that encourages you to poke and prod at its structure
votesFunny: almost everyone I know who've played this walked away from this game with a different story to tell.\n\nDepending on how your experience plays out
commentsCount: at some stage or another you will no doubt be forced to return to Stanley's office to once again set out to look for your co-workers
column16: and it's here that you might decide to stop playing the game and that's totally fine
column17: but in my experience
column18: once you've been presented with so many variables
column19: it's very hard to resist that urge to go back and try out every possible deviation
column20: especially when they can alter the game so radically beyond your expectations.\n\nAnd this kind of thinking is just so refreshing
column21: I found myself laughing with confusion and disbelief because every time I pushed the game
column22: it would push back. I guess the only disappointing moment was when I came to the stark realisation that the game couldn't possibly live up to the illusion of infinite choice. However this was more bitter sweet
column23: as I soon came to the realisation that any game that gave me this feeling of absolute freedom
column24: if only for the briefest moment in time
column25: was truly remarkable.\n\nThe Stanley Parable might not be for everyone
column26:
but in my opinion it should be played by everyone. It's a hilarious experiment in psychology and non-linear game design that will probably teach you more about yourself as a gamer than you might want to know.



"

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is very in love with itself.

As what I can only describe as an abstract rumination on contemporary game design, Galactic Caf√©‚Äôs The Stanley Parable is, from its opening moments, confident to the point of near irreverence. I suppose it‚Äôs understandable to a degree, as The Stanley Parable is undeniably witty and unconventional, with a quirky charm and dry self-awareness. It is so overwhelmingly eccentric that it can begin to feel as if not playing along with it and laughing at every joke is an act of disrespect, such is the perception The Stanley Parable cultivates within moments of leaving the main menu to venture forth into a cornucopia of contextually appropriate satire and bizarre dark humor.

The Stanley Parable gives off such a sense of self-prescribed brilliance that I feel both dumbfounded and maybe even a little angry at just how much I dislike it. I get the joke and admire its delivery, but when approached from any angle but the one the game so strongly attempts to cultivate, The Stanley Parable feels like little more than a few intelligent observations on modern game design strung along by a series of amusing, yet immensely inconsistent and inscrutable scenes with no conclusions to be found.

I understand that the lack of closure is part of the point. I can find a certain poetic appreciation for the circular design of the game, and as a lesson in abstract game design The Stanley Parable certainly gets marks for trying. But then it tries some more, and eventually (which is to say sometime within the first 20 minutes of play) I became rather weary of hearing the same joke play out as I raged a supposedly hilarious war with the narrator over increasingly innocuous choices.

There is such an abundance of creativity to be admired within The Stanley Parable, one would think that even in worst case scenarios everyone will be able to find something to like buried in its labyrinth of compounding decisions. But by design each disconnected moment is compiled with the next, creating a sequence of random and oddly directed scenes for which the primary goal is to disorient the player as they continue bumbling through a game with no rules and a rather antagonistic sense of progression.

The Stanley Parable without a doubt knows what it‚Äôs doing. The script is tight, the pacing smooth, and the overall concept worthy of praise. And yet I found myself despising every moment I spent with the game. The more I tried to peel back its layers to find the game I had seen praised to the ends of the earth and back, the more I was confronted with the same shallow and narcissistic experience that only became more meandering and unfulfilling the longer I stuck with it. I suppose it was fitting that I eventually arrived in a museum dedicated to the game itself; an internal monument to a project which clearly recognizes its own genius even as I struggle to understand the appeal.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
Are you an experienced gamer?  Have you played enough games that you instinctively recognize the tropes and common things that all games do, but can't quite put a finger on them?  Would you like a game that points them all out, and makes it amusing at the same time?  Good.  The Stanley Parable does that.

Well, I mean, that's where it starts.  First it puts its finger right on those tropes, pointing them out, having a chuckle.  Then the whole hand.  Then it shoves its hand through the tropes and the wall behind them, shattering a hole into a Escher-like dimension of allegory and humor spiraling endlessly around a story that deliberately falls afoul of the same tropes it works so hard to identify and undermine.

Then the game restarts, or maybe it doesn't restart.  Maybe you restarted it, but did you restart it because you wanted to, or because the game wanted you to?  And is this really a game anymore?

To perhaps make that rambling a bit more clear, The Stanley Parable is a game about a man, which is really allegory about games, which in turn is a metaphor about life and choice and free will and about a billion other things.  There are so many layers to the story you could get lost in it all, but the beauty is that you don't have to.  You can be philisophical about what it all means, or you can simply laugh hysterically at the spot on narration describing, bemoaning, and sometimes belittling you, the story, and who knows what else.

In short, The Stanley Parable is a beautiful mix of humor, philosophy, allegory, and self-aware commentary on video games, requiring almost no skill to understand and enjoy.  It is a masterpiece that blurs the line between game, story, commentary, and art.

reviewText: A flawlessly executed analysis of gaming conventions, spoken and unspoken. Like its contemporary fellow experience-a-thons Gone Home and Dear Esther, it's a bold innovation in storytelling. Also like Gone Home and Dear Esther, it's a far better experience the less you know about it beforehand. If you like great writing, acting, presentation and something meaningful to take away, and you haven't played The Stanley Parable, you're missing out.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is, without any doubt, one of the best headaches I've ever had. Even though it's more of a self-telling short story than a video game, you'll have yourself shaking your head and chuckling every time you walk through it... because your walkthrough will change with the smallest decision.

The Pros:
¬∑ Great and entertaining narration will follow every step you take...
¬∑ ... and every step you take feels surprisingly drastic, as something as little as going left or right will determine the way the story is told.
¬∑ Every decision you make will spin its own web, making it a joy to replay as it will rarely be the same.
¬∑ Asides from the light and humoristic narration, the game actually manages to adress some things we rarely think about, what gives you a unique sense of vulnerability even though not a single bullet will be shot or axe swung. You will have complete freedom, yet you're trapped from the very beginning.

The Cons:
¬∑ Even though there are many different ways you can go, the options aren't limitless. There is no real reason to play through the game the exact same way multiple times.
¬∑ Definately not for everyone. It's pure exploration that minimalises gameplay to simple environmental interactions with buttons and doors.

The Looks:
¬∑ The Stanley Parable runs on the Source Engine, and that shows... in a good way. The lighting and textures are phenomenal and soak you into the game's unique atmosphere that complements the entire story you get to tell.

Final Verdict:
Although it won't be for everyone, The Stanley Parable manages to suck you into its complexely simple story that is a joy to discover and rediscover differently the next time you play it. 8/10.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is a very interesting. It tells some fantastic jokes, makes some self-indulgent commentary, but then it proceeds to get stranger and more intimate and less pointed and more interesting the more you poke at it. It isn't making fun of games for the sake of some self-appointed enlightened savior of gaming and it doesn't seem to be strange for the sake of strangeness.

What makes Stanley Parable feel so fresh isn't the humor or the satire or the criticsm that's baked into it--those are enjyoable, but they weren't what impressed me. What makes it feel fresh is how intimately it converses with the player. I'm reminded very much of a game called Save the Date--though that was a smaller and simpler affair. Both games start with meta commentary and then submerge from there, talking carefully with you about how the narrator, creator or other characters think, feel and the ramifications of that for your behavior and your experience of the product. The secret of both of these games which drape themselves in the trappings of meta-narrative is that they do actually contain characters who you will learn about, be asked to empathize with, be asked to listen to, and be asked, after it all, to act on your conclusions should you have reached any.

They are games that start with the nature of games, then the nature of reality, and then quietly, timidly, reveal that at their heart they are about the same intimacies and relationships as most intersting or moving stories. For all of the delightful jokes, strangeness, non-linearity and surreality of The Stanley Parable my most clear feeling when I stopped playing was one of loss; I had run out of ways to communicate with this person with whom I formed a relationship. I had run out of things to say and ways to prove I was listening.

I was alone.

reviewText:
9.2/10 - A game where Office Space meets Groundhog Day!

This game does it right, great graphics and amazing narration. You are Stanley an employee who pushes buttons and does what he's told. You can follow the narrator‚Äôs directions or choose another path at your own risk.

The game is really short and meant to be played a plethora of times. Each time you play you will discover something else and uncover more dialogue.

The achievements are random, irrelevant and worth pursuing. I wouldn't pay $15, since i do have to play this game in smaller doses. Although this game is amazing; it can get little tedious finding new paths each time.

Worth $10

reviewText:
I am slightly conflicted about giving a negative review for this game. The game seems witty enough. There is a narrator and he does a wonderful job.

However, there's not much to really do apart from walk around and listen to the narrator. The amount of content is severely lacking - you could 'finish' the game within 5 minutes, although it is meant to be played through more than once. The replayability, which is supposed to be one of the game's strong suits, eventually becomes a weakness. Once you've seen an ending, you may not want to bother seeing it again.

The Stanley Parable reminded me of a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' book, but choice alone does not lend itself very well to gaming. Interaction is what makes gaming different and fun, and the game has little interaction further than choosing which door to enter.

I don't think The Stanley Parable lives up to all the praise that is heaped on it (mainly by critics). If you're going to get it, wait until it is heavily discounted. Or get Antichamber instead.

reviewText:
I'm not sure I should be writing this review yet, because I'm not sure I've reached every ending yet. I think I've broken double digits? Whatever, not running a game into the ground hasn't stopped me before, so here it is!
Buy it. Boom. Done. You need this game in your life. Because it's not just a game, but a story. And not a story like most first person shooters are stories, but it's a story that's 100% about player choice. Some of these choices are hilarious (the Confusion Ending, the Whiteboard Ending) while other result in your death (the Escape Ending, the Downstairs Ending); many of them find a way to re-route you to the beginning of the game, with minor cosmetic changes that leave you uncertain as to whether or not you're truly restarting.
The game's primary draw has to be the narration. The VO is soothing, witty, full of emotion; it's also surprisingly complete, with many dialogues going on much longer than one would expect. The game is all about the joy of discovery, and the narration encapsulates this perfectly, as you can't wait to hear what he says next.
Because of the nature of The Stanley Parable, it does get repetitive after a while. This is why it's best to set aside a full day (preferably a Tuesday) to play through everything at once, so the game can continuously update itself for you. It'll be a good day, I promise.

HEY! HEY! Wait just a minute, Nikki. Don't you trust me? You've already ran off the beaten path again, and I'm just worried that you may ru--

NO! NO! NO! Not again. Geez, Nikki. I thought you were better than this. I really did. *sighs* You don't really care, do you? You never do. Fine, just go on and do whatever it is that excites you. I'll be waiting for you to come back right here. No no no, don't worry about me. I'll be fine. Just...go.

reviewText:
The Definitive Review of The Stanley Parable

So, I was browsing through the Stanley Parable community page, and I inevitably ended up coming across a number of reviews. To be honest, I was actually surprised at how many negative reviews it got, and not just a bit disturbed at how many people found those reviews ‚Äúhelpful.‚Äù After reading several of those reviews, I came to the conclusion that many gamers do not really understand The Stanley Parable or how to go about playing it.

The first and most important thing I feel like I should address comes from the several reviews I read which stated how they ‚Äúbeat the game‚Äù in such a short amount of time, and how that made it not worth the money. The thing is, The Stanley Parable is not by any means a normal game. In fact, as many people have pointed out all over the place in a somewhat fanboyish fashion, it is not even really a ‚Äúgame‚Äù at all, in the familiar sense of the word. It is, in fact, exactly what it says it is: a parable. For those who don't really know what that is (don't be ashamed: I had to look it up, too), here's the definition, courtesy of the late Ms. Merriam-Webster:

par¬∑a¬∑ble
noun \Ààpa-r…ô-b…ôl\na short story that teaches a moral or spiritual lesson

The point is, you can't ‚Äúbeat‚Äù The Stanley Parable any more than you could beat a movie or a book. You can finish it, true. Once you've found every ending and heard every bit of dialogue, you can safely say that you've finished it; but there's no award at the end, no ‚ÄúStory Progress: 100%,‚Äù no achievement for finding all of the endings, nothing at all to say that you've ‚Äúbeaten‚Äù it. And besides, ‚Äúbeating‚Äù something implies that there was a challenge in the first place. The Stanley Parable isn't about any challenge; it's about exploration and discovery, along with some intriguing and entertaining psychological wizardry.

Now I've talked about the ‚Äúbeat the game‚Äù part, I want to discuss the ‚Äúlength‚Äù of the game a bit. Basically, The Stanley Parable is short for a reason. Each ending probably takes no more than half an hour to reach, often less. If all the endings took even just one hour, let alone the multiple hours most modern game storylines last, nobody would have the patience or curiosity to start over and find out what happens if you do it a different way.

In the end, The Stanley Parable may just not be for you. If you enjoy linear plot lines without pesky deviations and multiple endings, don't get it. If you don't have the patience to search for every possibly dialogue trigger, don't bother. If you get frustrated when you have to start something over, try something else. It's as simple as that. Think and research before you buy. If you wasted your money on The Stanley Parable, it's not because it failed to live up to your expectations, but because you did not know what to expect.

Finally, here is my verdict on The Stanley Parable. An enthusiastic thumbs-up, ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ, at least 94/100, whatever you want to call it; it is well-made, cleverly designed, and ingeniously implemented; the dialogue is involving, emotional, and filled with dry, quick-witted humor. In many ways it is very reminiscent of Portal ‚Äì it was made in Source, after all. I absolutely love it, and I highly recommend it.

Anyways, this was more or less a product of my boredom. I hope it was nevertheless helpful to some people. I did try to stay objective, except during that last paragraph, and I hope I succeeded in that. Enjoy your day, and enjoy The Stanley Parable. I know I do.

Not insincerely,
~~~~~~~TheQZ

reviewText:
The first time I launched the Stanely Parable, the game actually broke within a minute or so and wouldn't let me continue, leaving me with a shell of a doorway and no escape, only to have myself become lodged inside of a half-closed door until the end of time. Then I tried it again and had a proper metafying experience as I was originally meant to. It lead me to consider what was even the game's doing and what was me somehow making everything break, etc.

All that aside, awesome game if you're into exploring outside of the box experiences as well as a fair sense of humor. Similar to another 'experience' on steam called 'The Path', you get a clear sense of direction on what you're meant to do, and only when deciding you want to be a punk-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• nay-sayer do you really find out what's what.

TLDR;

its a game where you can't lose :D

reviewText:
Try the demo. It's not really a demo, but another piece of the game. Maybe the game is the demo. It's an awfully nice demo, if so.

Remember how Portal was awful funny, but then every so often the jokes would stop while you had to figure out how to fling yourself past five million turrets without being riddled with bullets and falling into toxic waste? This is more like the awful funny bits mainlined without the puzzling and getting shot part.

If you do play it, make sure to play it more than once, there are many different paths, some of which... well. It's a bit like an onion. Instead of making your eyes water, though, there are jokes.

Try the demo.

reviewText:
Endless choices, endless possibilites. Linear, yet non-linear. You could quite honestly replay this game again and again, wondering if you've gotten all the possible choices, all the secrets, and more. I guess you could say I techincally beat the game, but I can't help but wonder if it's beaten? I typically like to do my reviews after actually completing the game, so since I techincally beat it by getting to the endpoint of the game where there's nothing more to do with the current playthrough, I decided to do a review. I might as well do it now as it's become clear that I could pour more hours into it, getting in more different possibilities, wondering if I've got them all or how many of them there actually are.

I always knew I had a bad sense of directions, but this game just proved it big time. Constantly going against the narrorator, seeing what would come of it. Eventually ended up with Minecraft as a reward. An eventually an old, run-down office building. *Fun* That's when it sunk in that the possiblies seem to be endless. Well, obviously not endless as it's impossible, but it sure feels like it.

A game without objectives, puzzles, and all that other stuff, but at it's core, a deep, emotional story, especially if you think about it. A game with high replay value, meant to be played over and over again just to see different reactions, different possibilites, and more. A strange, but unique and great game. Not for everyone, but I'd definitely recommend it to anyone, that they at least give it a try, as I believe it to be a great game. A short, yet not short game. Two thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
Stanley Parable is a sarcastic commentary on the generic structure of video games and the trivial efforts of addicted gamers within them. Throughout the game, the narrator implicitly mocks the linear structure of gaming design, achievements, winning conditions, and choices. Recently we have open world/roguelike/sandbox games but still the majority of the most popular titles are quest-driven and poorly/linearly designed.

The Stanley Parable subverts stereotypical elements of video games. For example;

-There is no winning condition in TSP so it is impossible to beat the game. There is no legitimate ending and beginning. Storyline is twisty and unpredictable. TSP makes you question why we are so preoccupied with the idea of winning and completing quests.

- Do choices really matter in games? No matter what you choose, you always operate within the confines of the game structure. Escaping from the reality in real world, you are confined in a fictional digital world. And like real life, true choices are just an illusion.

- Why there is no midway between dying and following the narrator or NPCs. Witnessing the terror and panic of the narrator, when you do not follow his orders, you realize that it is really fun to step out ot the script and the linear boundaries of the game.

TSP is really clever and accurate in presenting the philosophical questions and criticism on the current status quo of the gaming industry, deconstructing the linear structure of game titles and leading gamers to interpret how they interact with game mechanics and narration in their pseudo-characters in the digital world.

reviewText: I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• off a disembodied voice. Also, it's fun and beautiful and will mess with your head, which are all good things in my book. I especially appreciated the little details - the projector not lining up perfectly with the screen, the captions on all the pictures in your boss's office... To top it all off, the developers are really excellent, friendly people who will actually talk to you if you take the time to write to them, and genuinely want to help people have a good time. So get the game and play it, and don't worry about the definition of a game. Just enjoy yourself and prepare for lots of laughs and a few disturbing moments of painful self-awareness.

reviewText:
On the surface, it's a game with very little interaction other than movement and the occasional button pressing, made hilarious and brilliant by dialogue alone... but deeper down it's a strangely profound game about making choices, and at times, incredibly disturbing.

Has a very similar feel to Portal, just without the actual puzzles and portals. (Atmosphere, world design, dialogue, humour)

PLAY THE DEMO. Really, it contains different content from the game and still gives you a feel for what it's like.

reviewText: The Stanley Parable is best described as a mind screw, but in a good way. In the game you play a character named, oddly enough named Stanley. Or do you? Is he game playing you? Are you playing YOU in the game or Stanley? This game goes so many ways and gives the player the choice to go and break the game. But even when you ‚Äúbreak‚Äù the game it is still only a choice the game allows the player to make. The other important character in the game other than the player is The Narrator. Go Play it. sm

reviewText:
Brief Review

The narrator guides Stanley, the game's protagonist, through a surreal environment while the narrator, delivers exposition. The player has the opportunity to make numerous decisions on which paths to take, and because at times the narrator says what Stanley will do next, the player can choose to ignore the narration and make a different choice. Every choice made by the player is commented on by the narrator, and depending on the choices the player makes, they will encounter different endings to the game before it restarts.

Pros and Cons

Pros

Astute, witty commentary on video game tropes
Narrator's voice is so, so good
Spectacularly funny
Choices that offer delightfully surprising results
Incredibly smart


Cons

Finding the last few endings is tedious
When you find an action without commentary, you'll feel sad


An Ending

The Stanley Parable is an exceptional game. By that, I don't necessarily mean it's especially great ‚Äì for it's certainly not to everyone's taste ‚Äì but it is unusual. It's so distinctly unusual that there's simply nothing it can be compared to

reviewText:
This is a game. It's also not a game. If I had to give it a rating, I'd rate it 88888888/10. But I don't have to give it a rating. I don't have to do anything. I can just sit in this room if I want... Yes, the end will be here soon. Very soon.

(the end is never the end is never the end is never the end is never)

I recommend The Stanley Parable to anyone who hates doing what they're told. I also recommend it to anyone who loves doing what they're told. I especially recommend it to those who like to click on doors, particularly doors that do not open. Personally I wouldn't pay full price to click on doors, but I'd happily pay sale price.

reviewText:
A lot of people think that The Stanley Parable is a difficult game to describe, but I don't think it is that hard. It is a game about storytelling and player choice in video games. It is very aware of the fact that it is a video game, and there are many jokes about how games operate and the kinds of choices that you are allowed to make in them. As an avid story-based game player, I enjoyed the humor immensely. If this kind of meta-humor sounds at all interesting, go try out the demo. Even if you know you are going to buy the game, play the demo anyway because the content of the demo is not in the full game. Because this humor is really the core of the game, the more I tell you about the game, the less you will get out of it when you play it; it is best to discover everything for yourself. Therefore I want you to stop reading this review as soon as you are convinced to play the game. If you make it to the end and are still not convinced, then you and I have very different tastes and I don't know why you take my advice on anything entertainment related.



A voice narrates your journey as you play as Stanley, an office worker who realizes that nobody is in the office building today. The narrator will tell you the path that Stanley took, but you are often free to try another path. The narrator will try to convince you to get back on track. At first he tries to rationalize why Stanley went the wrong way in the context of the story he is telling, but it doesn't take him long to break the fourth wall and address the player directly. There are many different branching paths in the game, but don't worry; the game starts back from the beginning when you get to the end of any of them.

One of my favorite wall-breaking moments involved the broom closet above.
The first time I played through, I tried to open every single door I came across. When the broom closet unexpectedly opened, I went inside. The narrator said, Stanley went into the broom closet
date: but seeing that there was nothing in there he turned around and got back on track." So I did.\nThe second time I went into the broom closet again
hoursPlayed: "Seriously? I'm not even going to narrate this for you. Just do whatever it is you think is worth going into a broom closet for
voteText:
and then let's get back to the story. I can wait."
The third time the broom closet was boarded up. I laughed for a good 30 seconds.

There were of course the mandatory jokes about office life
helpfulPercent: and how pointless meetings can be.\n\nIf you defy the narrator enough times in one play through
votesHelpful:
the game world will start to deteriorate and the narrator will panic. That was a really fun thread.

There is also a museum about the game and the creation of the game within the game. That was probably the most meta moment in the game.

Then there was the time that the narrator tried to improve the game by adding more choices and global leader boards. He even decided to show you some other games that he did not make
votesTotal: namely Minecraft and Portal.\n\nMost of these are very silly
votesFunny: but some were much more serious and/or philosophical. In one Stanley thought he was in a dream
commentsCount: because that was the only explanation he could think of for all of the video game logic (he couldn't see his feet
column16: the doors automatically closed behind him
column17: etc.) In another Stanley died.\n\nAchievement hunting in The Stanley Parable is an absolute riot. Only a couple of the achievements are obtained through traditional means. Others are found in the main menu
column18: or require you to exit the game and come back to it
column19: or play throughout a Tuesday. Yeah
column20: they're pretty intense.\n\nSeriously
column21: you should go get The Stanley Parable
column22: it will be the best two hours of your day. Even if you think the $15 price tag is too much for such a short game
column23: you should at least check out the demo. You won't regret it."

reviewText:
James stared at the blank text entry quadrangle trying to piece together his thoughts on The Stanley Parable.  He thought back at all the good times he had with Stanley, the Narrator, and The Adventure Line.  But a thought crossed his mind, is it really a game?  The setting, story and dialogue are all there (with quite high quality voice acting even!), but what of the gameplay?  Is the mere act of movement enough of a world and pushing buttons, gameplay?

James then realized the obvious: it did not matter.  What is important is the same thing that is important in all other games, the experiance.  As James looked over the hour's played count for The Stanley Parable, he noticed that he had poured hours into it, much of which were spent joyously listening to the narrator's witty remarks.

James recommends the game highly.

reviewText: At first, this game seemed simple, the videos provided only more confusion, and as i continued through this game my mind only drew deeper into this black hoel they call Stanley Parable... Stanley's state of mind was simliar to mine confused stuck, yet when given this opurtunity to change we took it. But as i found the narrator's words luring me even deeper into this game i coudn't help but walk forward, even when many parts would say to stop, ignore them, but i found the bond between them hypnotic.Not only could i not turn myself away from this game, i played it for 3 hours straight seemingly to play the same story over and over again, and i couldnt stop. And soon i found myself in stanley's shoes...the same thing over and over and over, never asking questions or changing my path. This was when i truly understood the stanley parable, you stay with him through the narrator's moments and his struggles. You just can't stop, you must play with stanley, fight with him, struggle with him, and find each other on a deeper level. His speechlesness only makes you work harder, though he stays silent he speeks thousands of words in his actions and his feelings with the narrator. You think after a while you would be finished with them, but you truly fall in love with both these charecters as you travel through this black hole and soon find yourself on the other side in a world of love and freindship.\n\nIf you dont play this game, your mentally ill, bring stanley into your life, you will find his love like i have and will never give up on him.10/10 Stanley is jesus.

This time I will not provide an extensive review put just leave some notes. First off, I'm giving it a thumbs up but for some people this title is probably not worth its full price - wait for a sale if you're in doubt.
Anyway, stop reading now because the following will contain spoilers - no game breaking ones but spoilers which spoil the gameplay and will take away some of your own experience and exploration and most of the free approach to the game. Starting now [ongoing SPOILER ALERT]:

For me it comes to a double-edged sword regarding this game. There is one big and simple reason: If you consider the conserative way and understanding of beating a game in this case you do so by simply following the rules of the game - namely the primary intention of the narrator. So the primary way - sticking to the rule set" - will directly lead you to one end of the game - not THE end (there isn't one per se) - but one. reviewText:
This is a review of a story about Stanley.

The story has a simple start: Stanley finds himself in Room 427 and at the desk for Employee #427. But then, something feels amiss when no orders arrive on his monitor. While Stanley could very well close the door and meekly continue waiting, he also felt a compelling force directing him outside. Out through the door of Room 427 and out into the unknown, that is where the exciting story can begin.

When it does, the writing will leave you breathless. Oh, the twists and the turns of the plot, how they'll dazzle you. And let us not forget the witty commentary, the emotion-packed drama, the suspenseful sequences, and the mind-blowing revelations! A perfect example of everything thus described can be seen when...

Oh dear, I can't just tell you what happens. That would ruin the surprise of the story, and the story is the best part of The Stanley Parable. I can't just spill all the juicy details in a review like an ill-thought-out movie trailer. Why, it'd be like telling you about how Sasuke kills Dumbledore in that upcoming secret Harry Potter/Naruto crossover movie, or showing you that scene where Donald Duck is turned to the dark side by Sith Lord Deadpool in Kingdom Hearts VII. It would completely ruin the emotional impact when you finally experience the plot yourself, so it's a good thing I didn't spoil anything.

However, the question remains... how to convince you of the excellence inherent in The Stanley Parable when describing any part of its plot would ruin the experience for you. After all, it's not like you haven't already prowled around for trailers of the Stanley Parable, possibly located in a convenient central area where a collection of highly insightful and deeply moving trailers are gathered for perusal at one's leisure. Certainly, you wouldn't be here at all if you had listened to The Stanley Parable's inspirational and masterfully orchestrated music[syntheticorchestra.bandcamp.com], or wisely sought out the opinions of professional reviewers. Of course not, witnessing any of the things I had just described would have instantly led you to the logical decision of buying The Stanley Parable and playing it to your heart's content like a sensible human being.

Unless... ah, I see what you're doing. You're being savvy. Not so fast game developers
date: You doubtless say to yourself every morning. I don't buy based on irrational impulses. Much like the wise tortoises of yore
recommended: I too slowly and carefully consider various criteria before choosing which game I want to purchase."\n\nWell
hoursPlayed: there's not much else I can say

Will no entreaty convince you to let The Stanley Parable past your defenses and into your heart? Surely there must be one last thing that could tip the scales. Informative pamphlets? Videos of baby animals pretending to be Stanley? A comprehensive demonstration model of The Stanley Parable that accurately and effectively conveys The Stanley Parable experience[www.stanleyparable.com]? If only there was just one last thing!\n\nBut then again

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P4tBeT8wcpo&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA

A parable is defined as a succinct story which illustrates one or more
instructive lessons or principles using analogy. The Stanley Parable is a
narration based game told from a first person perspective .  Through the eyes
of the main character, Stanley, you are taken on many bizarre, twisting
adventures  narrated by sarcastic, hilarious inner dialogue that explore the
meaning of life, and ferns though parables.

The gameplay is fairly basic.  As you progress through the levels, it
offers choices that affect your current and future playthroughs. The level
design is layer upon layer of rooms that seem to twist in on themselves to
confuse your sense of direction and add to the story.  The story never truly
ends, until the player decides it does.

There is not a lot of depth in the game, but there is a lot of choice.
The story plus the narrations is entertaining, amusing, and charming, and worth
a few hours of play through.  It plays on our natural curiosity, making us
wonder what there is yet to discover.  The end is not the end

This is a summary of what I talk about in the video, I am a YT'er not a Blogger

reviewText:
Rating: 10/10

The Stanley Parable is a humourous satire on the absurdity of modern life, told using three themes almost all gamers can relate to in their personal lives: clich√©d story tropes used in fiction; strange restrictins in video game mechanics, particularly in level design; and the monotomy of working life. You play as Stanley, an office worker that finds himself alone when everyone has seemingly disappeared. Stanley travels from his office to investigate. Accompanied by an ironic and witty narrator, whom seems to know his every move and thought, Stanley moves through the office to uncover this mystery. As Stanley, you can either follow the directions of the narrator, or frustrate him by going against his narrations (read 'instructions') and create your own choices.

This isn't a traditional adventure game, with plot lines and character development. There are no players, enemies, weapons, combat, scores, levelling, or other elements usually considered mandatory for any sort of game. Rather, this is a story about discovering the absudity of life (see Heaven Ending") and how as people we simply accept a role in life that reduces our choices to a few points of interaction
date: where you aren't making decisions at all‚Äîyou're simply continuing to exist. Whether it's periodically pulling a lever or pushing a few buttons at a computer desk every day for decades until retirement
recommended: this game may inspire you to question whether you're really living a life of variety and fulfillment.\n\nThere are multiple endings and it's up to the persistence and creative disobedience of each player to discover them all. It'll take you around 2 hours to find all the endings
hoursPlayed: but you'll want to revisit particular endings every once so often

helpfulPercent: just to remind yourself of what you'll learn."

reviewText:
This is a game about the honorable knight of a modern century. Stanley uses his power of thought to fight against the realms of forgotten human fears. The fears all of us have. Almost all of us. Stanley isn't afraid of our mere troubles, they're way too small for his thoughtful brain. He is a hero.

Oh, the game, right. It takes place in space, where Stanley fights against demons disguised as giant stars. They will try  to seduce him, but we all know that this is impossible. Stanley cannot be controlled. He's the one controlling. He saves people and planents just on his own. Entire universe is fighting against him, but he will manage to strike back. He's a hero after all.

But Stanley isn't one of the shining armor knights riding a white horse. He's close to our human beings. He has feelings. He sleeps, he laughs, he coughs, he frightens, he washes floors for free being a nice generous guy. See? He's just like you and me. He will never  give up trying to prove to this world being a perfect person who deserves this title.

Levels? Who need them? The game runs perfectly well using two maps with giant attention to detail. Every piece of paper has it's own unique messages about Stanley being awesome. Every single chair has a bubblegum attached underneath. Even more: each gum has it's own flavour! Real revolution in game design will let you feel to be there, with Stanley.

The story adjusts to your game style! It may be either fast-paced or slow walk on a park. Or maybe you will run across that park with bunch of sharks on your tail. Stanley doesn't have a tail like most of us. Another similarity! You're pretty much alike with Stanley! Except he does what he wants.

But this game is not about what Stanley wants. This game is about what you want. You want to get another game where you play as a wizard,  because you want to be one, but simply can't. You want a game where you play as someone better than you. A game, where you can escape your daily routine and dive into a thriling adventure you will never get in your boring life. Stanley doesn't need neither you nor me nor anyone else. His story is perfect and complete.

But you want to see it in action. Let all those puppets dance just for you. You were not even paying attention to what I was saying. It's a human nature to be maximally boring and minimally paying any attention to the matter of facts. I bet you can't wait to finish reading this very review to post a comment about both grammatical mistakes I've made, or maybe even about double spaces. Why are you reading this then? Most of you has already played the game and read this just to find some person to mock up because of his writing or spelling skills. Because none of you make mistakes. You're all perfect. Like Stanley is.

reviewText:
You're paying for a 'sudden realization', not a game. A narrative and satire, not a game (but still a decent narrative. I enjoyed the narration for what it's worth. Kinda funny). Don't fall for the cryptic desciptions on steam thinking there's a mystery to solve that nobody wants to give away like I did.

The concept is pretty clever and it has it's moments but The Stanley Parable is still overpriced for what it offers in my opinion. I didn't exactly know what I was paying for when I bought it, but I heard/read it was somthing amazing and this and that. I'm not usually swayed by those types of reviews but this one had some type of psycological lure to it I couldnt resist. The  demo didn't clarify the game for me but made me more curious, so I guess it served it's purpose (lol).... When I actually bought it I expected a challenge of some sort, and because I don't like to be spoiled I was reluctant to read some reviews labled 'spoiler' or watch many videos. When I realized the 'point' of the stanley parable was the whole spoiler nobody wants to give away I stopped playing, feeling the same way alot of other reviwers did. . I felt like I could have watched someone play it for free and recieve the message just fine.

Moral of the story: Know what you're paying for. Really make sure you know what you're paying for...

reviewText: A high-quality remake (including more content) of the original title with the same name. It's a sort of choose-your-own-adventure with narration. A typical play-through is probably about 5 to 15 minutes, depending on the choices you take. The game is designed to be replayed multiple, multiple times. Awesome narration, clever humor and writing. I spent time looking at everything, and doing all the obvious choices that are presented, then looked up the additional ones and went through those. Took me about 3-4 hours to do so. Highly recommend this game, as well as the demo (which is completely new content, due to the nature of this game.) The original HL2 mod is also really good, but dated.

votesHelpful: The Stanley Parable is... something else. I don't want to spoil anything, and you should play the demo or watch the trailers to get an idea of the game's tone and the outstanding voice work of Kevan Brighting, if nothing else. That said, I loved every minute of the Stanley Parable, and though it is extremely short, there are multiple endings that all take the game in a completely different direction. If you want to laugh out loud, this is the game for you. Once you've seen everything there is to see, the game doesn't offer much replay value, but this is not an experience to be missed.

reviewText: I have maintained the notion for a number of years that video games are pieces of art, just as viable as books, paintings, and sculptures--in some ways more so.  There are games that are eyeball-poppingly beautiful, of course, and games that make your brain cells implode--looking at you, Crysis 3 and Bioshock Infinite--but I have never before found a game that really made the player delve into their own psyche, a game that surpassed the boundaries of common narative functions and made the player the true star of the show.\nThus enters this little game.  What can you do?  Walk around.  Sometimes, you interact with an object or two.  The only other being present is the brilliantly voiced narator.   Mostly, you walk, listen, walk some more, and listen some more.\nBut, oh, that's the beauty of it.  Forget gaming" mechanics
date: forget all the bells and whistles.  This game exists to get in your mind
recommended: where all the real action occurs.  It is a stunningly deep and riotously funny condiut for some of the most incredible glimpses of human nature I've had the pleasure of witnessing--via game or other media.  The Stanley Parable is a wonderful play for anyone with a sense of humor and a pension for self-examination.  This is a game about you--your importance

reviewText:
Play the demo.

No ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• excuses, do it. The demo is the turning point that decides all. If you get it, if you find it enjoyable, then the full game is enjoyable. If you don't get what the demo is about, this game has nothing for you.

Stanley Parable is above all a humour game, and the style of humour depends heavily on your experience on all kinds of games. At most, it is a game that makes you laugh and think about video game concepts, at worst it makes you curse why isn't there anything to do.

Play the demo. Just do it and everyone will be made clear.

reviewText: An existentialist commentary on the nature of narrative and storytelling, The Stanley Parable satirizes video games themselves in a metaphysical first-person adventure game. Much like a philosophy text, attempting to condense anything about it would undermine the purpose; play it for yourself. Is it worth it? Absolutely.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Brilliant, brilliant game. Astonishing level of fourth-wall breaking, and an environment so consistent (while still being pretty simple) that it will capture you for long hours.

Look for secrets. There are lots of little details. Look for all of them. And then realise you've been excitedly going through the same hallway for a whole day. And it wasn't even Tuesday.

If you've never played a videogame, especially in first person, don't start with this one. It would be like choosing 2001 - A Space Odyssey to be the first movie you watch.

But if you have... then by all means, you must play The Stanley Parable. You have no idea.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An excellent adventure through narration that gives the player pause for thought about the limitations of choice while still having choice in a game.

It's fun, quirky, and worth a few playthroughs to give the game time to have you come to your own conclusions about narration, direction, trust, and choice.

There may or may not be skill trees, leaderboards, and/or exp, yet still in the end (or the beginning) I felt that I was left with a satisfying experience.

reviewText:
All I can say is, the game may look like Portal, and yes, it has a Portal feel to it, but don't go getting this game expecting Portal, because what you get is something completely different, but not a bad different.  Oh no-no-no.  This is a very good different.

Basically the game is supposedly about making decisions...

Which is true to some extent...

But what it basically comes down to is you going down each different route one after another hunting each ending you can possibly find, whilst being narrated by a rather charming and witty narrator.  Who IS basically the reason you play the game anyway.

Basically, if you enjoy intelligent humour and a video game that somewhat mocks other video games and film scenarios, then this is most definitely the game for you!  Whilst the game will sometimes hold your hand yo get you around, a lot of the time, you will find yourself wadering into a path you had never noticed the first time you went there before, even though it was there the whole time from the start.

I would most definitely recommend this game!
My rating: 88/100

reviewText: A pretty fun and unusual game. It's mostly a parody on certain mechanics used in games, most notably the idea of player choice. Throughout the entire time, there is a narrator speaking to the player, who is trying hard to guide the player along a certain direction. The player can then choose to listen to the narrator or wander off and do what they feel like, which gets on narrator's nerves.\n\nThere isn't all that much content in the game, and I kind of wish it had more, but what is there is certainly worth experiencing. The game is both funny and thought-provoking. Now
recommended: let's go and find the story." :D"

reviewText: It's one of those games where you walk around, but it's much more interactive than most. It responds to all your choices, and the main fun of the matter is taking things in unexpected directions to see if the game is ready for it. Most of the time, it is, and has a new story branch to go right along with it. They thought of almost everything. There are a great deal of possible endings to discover and a few hours of pure comedy to enjoy. If you're not into meta-comedy or mocking the basics of game design in general, you won't find much to laugh at, but as someone who enjoys this sort of thing, it's irresistibly clever, made better by its wonderful narrator.

reviewText:
When SpyroGuy launched this game he was confronted by the enormously dramatic weight that his choices are carrying during the course of this game's gameplay that is, until he stumbled upon a helplessly ferocious piece of hamburger lying across his path.
Without hesitation, SpyroGuy grabbed this hamburger, smashed it to pieces and proceeded on his way to find the knowledge he seeked. Little he knew tough that this hamburger was in fact a cleverly cloaked button which upon it's destruction has automatically activated the secret nuclear missiles hidden inside SpyroGuy's left pocket.

Some explosions happened and everyone was dead, including SpyroGuy. The End.

reviewText:
Just when you thought you could just complete the game by getting across the doors and beating the final boss....well, wait, there isn't a boss, just doors and possibilities.
So what choice will you make? Will you let the omniscient narrator take over your decisions, or will you fight off his control and follow your urges for freedom?

In earnest, you should let this game take over your free will, immerse yourself in this predetermined world where you have no say whatsoever, where you can just follow instructions. Do not try to jump, do not open the broom closet, click on the photocopier, don't go downstairs, take the door on the right. Oh and Just go and buy this game on the steam store.

WAIT! Did you just read this review and believe every word that was there? How could you blindly trust a random person writing a review and take up his advice to purchase something you would have no inclinations for?

Yes, you are quite right, exercise your free will and DON'T buy this game. It has absolutely no bearing on your life and given the choice to ignore it, you should just forget about it.

That's it, you did it, you are free now.

But what's this? That little nudge in a corner of your head telling you: what if...?". Indeed

reviewText:
This is a review about The Stanley Parable.  This is not a review about The Stanley Parable.

During the process of the first playthrough of The Stanley Parable you will think you're playing The Stanley Parable, but you're not.  The second time you play The Stanley Parable you will realize that the first time you played The Stanley Parable you didn't actually play The Stanley Parable and you will make your best effort to play The Stanley Parable, but you won't do it.  Eventually, after playing The Stanley Parable enough times you will realize that there is no playing The Stanley Parable.  There isn't.  No.

There is just you, and there is just The Stanley Parable.

Eventually you will realize that throughout the entire time playing, The Stanley Parable had been playing you.

And it was winning.

Story: 13/15 ........................ Visual Appeal: 6/10
Characters: 14/15 ................ Audio Appeal: 8/10
Gameplay: 7/15 ................... Machanics: 8/10
Atmosphere: 14/15 .............. Congruency: 10/10

Overall: 80%

reviewText:
Truly amazing. I wrote a review of the Demo and the original mod before the full game came out awhile back and never got around to writing a review for this one, but I can say that this was well worth the $15. For those who played the original, know that it is not just an HD remix of the original Source mod. It also adds plenty of new endings, as well as new secrets. The original made it quite obvious to the player the choices available and the amount of endings that could be had, but now they've changed plenty of things around to add more secrets, endings, and oh, the replayability!

Now, every time you finish the game, the game will begin again and sometimes after certain endings certain things will change, and it has some hilarious achievements, such as playing the game for the entire duration of a Tuesday, or not playing for five years, or the Unacheivable" acheivement (which is apparently somehow acheivable but I'm not sure how to legitly yet).

I definitely recommend this game to EVERYONE.

PS: Don't look up any videos or any information about it. It's best experienced first-hand; there's a reason the Store page tells you nothing about the game. If you aren't prepared to throw your money around without knowing about it
recommended: play the demo first. It has exclusive content from the actual game and is hilarious in its own right‚Äìit's the best Demo ever

column16: by systematically trying to apply the same mechanics he is usually applying to videogames in order to achieve the results he is used to achieve
column17: is substantially growing accustomed to mechanically do the same thing over and over
column18: without demanding anything extra-ordinary (uncommon) of himself nor leaving any space for free reflection. "Stanley [...] has a job that demands nothing of him
column19: and every button that he pushes is a reminder of the inconsequential nature of his existence. Look at him there: pushing buttons
column20: doing exactly what he's told to do. Now

As Stanley is not questioning the repetitiveness of his job so the player might not be questioning certain patterns that he is automatically following in his gameplay sessions; in The Stanley Parable these patterns are usually bringing the player to look for something that he's used to get in other games
column26: only to end up getting it in a very ridiculing form ( just think of the competitive leaderboards and the achievements ).\n\nIn most of the cases
column27: by giving the players exactly the contrary to what they wanted from the game
column28: The Stanley Parable pushes the player to obtain a sort of third person self analytical perspective (even intensified in one of the endings in which  the game ends with a third person view on Stanley incapable of making a choice )
column30: in which he is asked to reflect on the nature of his impulsive attractions or behaviours. The arising questions and the following thoughts are many: is what the players are looking for something really worth to look for
column31: or are they just grown accustomed to have it and therefore they're feeling its absence when it's not given to them? But it is only when this perspective is moved to other entertainment forms
column32: which are also demanding nothing of people and just drench them with a shower of positive or shocking stimuli
column33: that we can really start to question the level of free will that we possess; as Gustave Le Bon writes in his book "The Crowd ‚Äì A Study of the Popular Mind": ‚ÄùIt is only by obtaining some sort of insight into the psychology of crowds that it can be understood [...] how powerless they are to hold any opinions other than those which are imposed upon them
column34: and that is not with rules based on theories of pure equity that they are to be led

column36: or are we doing that to relief some of our personal frustrations by watching someone else failing? "Yes
column37: it's all very amusing. And we laugh and we call our friends over and they laugh too and soon the whole world laughs and laughs and laughs at the man who failed. [...] But [...] you

column39: why are we then allowing the frustration to latently exist? Are we so accustomed to our life as it is that we're scared of doing any changes? How many non-influenced choices are we making? What's the worth of those choices?\n\nStanley might be starting to understand all of this: "in and amongst his aimless meandering

and release some of its pedagogical potential? Afterall "men never shape their conduct upon the teaching of pure reason" as Le Bon writes

reviewText: Put Groundhog Day, Office Space, Portal, and Monty Python in a blender and whip up this fantastic treat.  It‚Äôs anarchic, surreal, witty, and hilarious.  I keep thinking about that Flying Circus episode where Eric Idle keeps yelling Start again!"  The concept is inspiring
date: especially for gamers from the old school who are very aware of what games were like before choice was a consideration in game design.  It's also thought-provoking for those of us that have had (or still have) cubicle jobs where our work life seems like little more than a calculated series of button presses.  Highly recommended
recommended: with this caveat:  put your expectations aside."

reviewText:
Truly amazing. I wrote a review of the Demo and the original mod before the full game came out awhile back and never got around to writing a review for this one, but I can say that this was well worth the $15. For those who played the original, know that it is not just an HD remix of the original Source mod. It also adds plenty of new endings, as well as new secrets. The original made it quite obvious to the player the choices available and the amount of endings that could be had, but now they've changed plenty of things around to add more secrets, endings, and oh, the replayability!

Now, every time you finish the game, the game will begin again and sometimes after certain endings certain things will change, and it has some hilarious achievements, such as playing the game for the entire duration of a Tuesday, or not playing for five years, or the Unacheivable" acheivement (which is apparently somehow acheivable but I'm not sure how to legitly yet).

I definitely recommend this game to EVERYONE.

PS: Don't look up any videos or any information about it. It's best experienced first-hand; there's a reason the Store page tells you nothing about the game. If you aren't prepared to throw your money around without knowing about it

reviewText:
‚ÄúThis is a story of a man named Stanley‚Äù
Premise
In The Stanley Parable, the player takes on the role of a man simply named Stanley. Stanley‚Äôs job is just as simple as his name: an average everyday office worker. The only thing that sounds more boring than Stanley‚Äôs job and name, are his job requirements: press certain buttons as directed by a computer monitor. But don‚Äôt let this boring premise deter you from this game, it‚Äôs brilliant beyond measure.

Despite sounding mindless, Stanley has a passion for his boring office job. Such a mindless passion, that when the orders stop coming in for him to press buttons from the monitor, he waits an entire hour beginning to question the lack of instruction. It‚Äôs this lack of instruction that causes Stanley to become self aware for the first time in his career (and possibly his life), and drives the beginning of the game. It also helps him notice other strange occurrences around the office and makes him ask questions. Where did my co-workers go? Did I miss a memo? Stanley finally has to make his own choices. He has to speak up. He has to think on his own. Where to I walk? What do I interact with? Stanley had been shielded from independent thinking his entire life it appears, all thanks to a computer monitor always telling him what to do. The choices and the independent thinking are where the finally player comes in, and where the excitement of the game is found. Or more accurately, the lack of choice is where the amusement is found. Mwahahahah. Ahem, carrying on.

Bulk of Review
Choices (and the lack of) are undoubtedly the cause of entertainment and humor in this game, but it‚Äôs the way these choices go hand-in-hand with the witty commentary that makes this game truly amusing. Wait, commentary? What commentary? I think it's a point of emphasis that I mention this a narration-driven game. When Stanley finally gains awareness, a narrator begins to narrate Stanley‚Äôs story audibly, remarking his thoughts and actions. The narrator is the one who woke up Stanley from his mindless slumber in the first place. He decides of what happens in the story just as much as the player does. Scratch that-- the narrator is an all powerful omnipotent being who limits the player in every thinkable way possible. That‚Äôs the point of the game in a nutshell.

The thrill of the game is toying with the soothing narrator, who comments on every action and choice the player makes, or for that matter, refuses to make. The narrator not only makes comments, but directs and eventually commands Stanley to go down certain passageways and up certain staircases. He wants to control Stanley as much as you yearn to rebel against him. The true amusement is resisting and compromising with the narrator when he directs you to go down a hallway or through a door. In essence, that is the idea of the game. The struggle for control between the narrator of you and you-- No, not this door, I‚Äôll go through this hallway instead. The narrator‚Äôs frustration and responses with his own character is hilarious and the most thought out part of this game.

The game has very little visual feedback and reinforcement, which can be it‚Äôs downfall and it‚Äôs strength depending on the person. In most cases, I‚Äôd call it a strength. The player can only interact with a handful of objects, which are limited to doors, computers and buttons. This is what makes The Stanley Parable a breath of fresh air. For the first time in my gaming experience, a game relies on the majority of it‚Äôs feedback being audible instead of visual. That‚Äôs a strikingly new concept despite how simple it is to implement and carry out.

If you like the Portal franchise or puzzle games like Antichamber, The Stanley Parable is comparable to a good mix of both, while still maintaining it‚Äôs own personality as a video game. The witty commentary and it‚Äôs amusement that comes with it draws an easy parallel between Portal and The Stanley Parable. If you like GLaDOS‚Äôs company, the game will do a excellent job of keeping you entertained. This game best caters to those who are willing to question everything in the room, and have an eye for patterns and details. The game has a total of 18 different endings depending on how you and the narrator get along, and how well you can think for yourself despite having limited alternatives to what the narrator says.

Some Criticism
So what is this game lacking? Choice. Despite the fact lack of choice is one of the key features of the game, it‚Äôs nonetheless a bit too limited. The vast majority of doors go unlocked and sometimes the player feels very forced into complying with the narrator. Of course, it‚Äôs worth noting the game itself is a analysis on the state of choice in video games. In video games as a medium, we are often more limited with our choices than we care to admit. The Stanley Parable makes light of this. We tend to accept the premise prematurely often too much. We blindly accept the number of choices that are presented, are the number of choices there are. Even with that being the case, the game needs more endings. 18 endings is great, but I feel there is a perfect threshold for this game to capture so it can still make it‚Äôs point about the lack of choice, and have more choice. Perhaps I‚Äôm sour I‚Äôve completed the game and found all the endings, but hey, who wouldn‚Äôt want to rebel against an omnipotent soothing narrator a little more?

Conclusion
Currently, The Stanley Parable goes for a decent $15 on Steam. At best, it will give you 7 hours of gameplay if you‚Äôre sure to analyze every detail. For the average player however, 3 hours is what‚Äôs expected. Due to the nature of the game, it‚Äôs a rainy day experience. And while it has brilliant commentary and thought-provoking critique on the nature of choice in video games, $15 is a bit much for a day‚Äôs worth of entertainment. I‚Äôd strongly recommend waiting for a sale, but if you love Portal and soothing voices, I can empathize if you can‚Äôt.


A Fair Recommendation - 8.7/10

reviewText:
This is a review of The Stanley Parable.

It is important to recognize that this is only the opinion of the reviewer, and not of you, the potential buyer. Having a separate opinion is perfectly acceptable, and makes you special and unique.

In fact, I would recommend forming your own opinion on just about everything in your life. Try doing so now, by looking around your current surroundings, and picking an object nearby (a pencil, cup, or piece of paper will do nicely). Now, try and form your own opinion about that object.

I'll wait.

...

hmmm hmmm hmmmm.....

...

Have you formed an opinion yet?

Good!

Now, imagine that opinion was about this game. Makes this game that much more appealing, doesn't it? Unless you have a negative opinion, in which case you haven't done this right, and need to reevaluate your worth to society.

Oh, I see, you must be having trouble applying an opinion to the game? Ahhh...  you haven't bought the game yet. This is fine at the moment, but is really putting you at a loss in this review.  Let me guess, you must want to wait and reserve your opinion until after you have played the game?

That shows wisdom.

If you MUST see what this game is like,  I would recommend the demo, which is in fact free.  Actually, I will go ahead and review the demo for you. It is fantastic! Better than any other free demo about the Stanley Parable I have played. well worth your time if you are, in fact, interested in The Stanley Parable. Which I am guessing you are, as you are still reading this.

Now, where was I?

Oh yes! The Stanley Parable review.  Unfortunately I must hold off on that at the moment, as someone picked the door on the right, and I need to have a talk with them about the implications of such an action.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To describe anything about the game, that is to describe any scene that is going on in the game, any moment that stood out to me would be telling you too much. It would be too big a spoiler, no matter how insignificant the scene might seem. For nothing is really insignificant in the Stanley Parable. A butterfly flaps its wings and creates a hurricane, Stanley does something and chaos ensues.

You can follow the narrator, or you can disobey him and watch what happens. What does happen would be a spoiler, however it leads to both hilarious dialogue and at the same time, somehow, without sacrificing comedy, it manages to make you think things over. It manages to question the nature of choice and free will. Are you truly free to do anything in the Stanley Parable? After all, the game has been predetermined, hasn't it? It has been built by a developer, and as such as a finite number of endings... But that's the thing, it never seems to end. Even after playing it for four hours straight, I had only found what, 7 endings? And I'm sure there's more to find, since I only explored the endings from the choices you were given, and I am told there are 18.

Speaking of the narrator, you thought GLaDOS was good? This is basically GLaDOS on steroids. His voice is soothing, he is well written, and he has the right amount of intonation into everything he says, every line is delivered to perfection.

The only complaint I could possibly have about the game is that it's on the short side, but that's good. It's like the original Portal, its length means that it doesn't overstay its welcome and that it keeps everything fresh.

If I had to give it a number, I'd give it a solid 10 out of 10.

reviewText: There, more or less, is no such thing as a good, spoiler-free review of this game. After all, what makes this game so ridiculously ingenious, darkly comical and chillingly haunting can only re/ally be captured within examples from the dynamic and somehow engaging tale. Plus, most of what the story is about is discovered over time and unraveled throughout the game. I'll do my best all the same.\nYou are cast into an eerily vacant office space, full of mystery and the echoes of an ironic and altogether fitting British man giving you orders by means of telling your story, before it actually happens. I won't give too much detail for fear of ruining it, but there often is a choice. Follow what you are told, or revolt against what you are told. It is up to you. I won't say any more. You need to find out for yourself.\nAlthough very short (completed in one and a half hours), this game captures emotion and pyscological elements in an indescribably unique way, and is an experience that cannot be missed. 9/10, absolutely astounding. Prepare for profuse mind blowing.

reviewText:
This is the story of a man named Carbon,

Carbon worked in his own home as a Part-time YouTuber were he was Carbon Helium. Carbon's job was simple: He sat at his desk in his room, and recorded footage of him playing games. Order's came to him via the comments on his videos, telling him what to play, how long, and who with. This is what Carbon did every day, of every month, of every year, and although others might have considered it boring, Carbon relished every moment someone commented on his video, as though he had been made exactly for this job. And Carbon was happy.

And then one day, Carbon downloaded the Stanley Parable, played it for a while, and posted a video on it. Then something very peculiar happened. Something that would forever change Carbon; something he would never quite forget. He had been at his desk for nearly an hour when he realized that not one single comment had been made on his new video. No one had shown up to give him hatred, constructive feedback, or even say 'hi.' Never in all his years at home had this happened, this complete isolation. Something was very clearly wrong.

Shocked, frozen solid, Carbon found himself unable to move for the longest time. But as he came to his wits and regained his senses, he got up from his desk and stepped out of his room.

All of his friends were gone, what could it mean? Carbon then realised he had been playing this game for way too long. That the year was now 2097, and everyone he knew was dead.

10/10, lost all my friends

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is an amazingly funny exploration game, with many different endings. It continually breaks the rules of video games in the most creative ways, and it manages to do this without becoming tedious or boring.

Every individual ending is a completely different experience, from trying to defuse a bomb, to being lectured about the importance of your choices, to playing through different video games, all leaving you shocked and surprised as you play. You can never truly see what is going to happen.

This, along with the excellent voice acting of the narrator makes an experience you wouldn't want to miss!

The only downside, is that the game does not have much replay value, as once you have experienced an ending, you will never get the same feeling of surprise.

Final Score: 9/10

column18: without demanding anything extra-ordinary (uncommon) of himself nor leaving any space for free reflection. "Stanley [...] has a job that demands nothing of him

As Stanley is not questioning the repetitiveness of his job so the player might not be questioning certain patterns that he is automatically following in his gameplay sessions; in The Stanley Parable these patterns are usually bringing the player to look for something that he's used to get in other games
column26: only to end up getting it in a very ridiculing form ( just think of the competitive leaderboards and the achievements ).\n\nIn most of the cases
column27: by giving the players exactly the contrary to what they wanted from the game
column28: The Stanley Parable pushes the player to obtain a sort of third person self analytical perspective (even intensified in one of the endings in which  the game ends with a third person view on Stanley incapable of making a choice )
column30: in which he is asked to reflect on the nature of his impulsive attractions or behaviours. The arising questions and the following thoughts are many: is what the players are looking for something really worth to look for
column31: or are they just grown accustomed to have it and therefore they're feeling its absence when it's not given to them? But it is only when this perspective is moved to other entertainment forms
column32: which are also demanding nothing of people and just drench them with a shower of positive or shocking stimuli
column33: that we can really start to question the level of free will that we possess; as Gustave Le Bon writes in his book "The Crowd ‚Äì A Study of the Popular Mind": ‚ÄùIt is only by obtaining some sort of insight into the psychology of crowds that it can be understood [...] how powerless they are to hold any opinions other than those which are imposed upon them

column36: or are we doing that to relief some of our personal frustrations by watching someone else failing? "Yes
column37: it's all very amusing. And we laugh and we call our friends over and they laugh too and soon the whole world laughs and laughs and laughs at the man who failed. [...] But [...] you

What's the worth of those choices?\n\nStanley might be starting to understand all of this: "in and amongst his aimless meandering
