I think I'm going to enjoy this. When you find out how alone you truly are.. I will be laughing more than anyone."

Is this a time in which we should break the old entertaining clich√©s of the videogame medium
and release some of its pedagogical potential? Afterall "men never shape their conduct upon the teaching of pure reason" as Le Bon writes

reviewText: I'm not even sure how I should begin to start telling you how this game is entertaining, Yeah sure, it isn't strictly a game, in the same sense that Minecraft is a creativity toy rather than a game, The Stanley Parable is more of a 'choose your own adventure' type thing, Because hell, what's a choose your own adventure without bizzare, unimaginable endings, Hell, you jump out of a window, there's a ending, you stay in a broom closet, there's an ending. All while having a narrator berate you strictly for not going through the left door. If you love watching Let's Plays for the commentator's intrepid sense of humour, you'll love hearing the Narrator, no matter what you do, he has some form of making you look like an absoulute ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. For ¬£10, this is a must buy for anyone who likes any of the following: Mind ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s, witty banter, tons of endings, being confused, thinking the broom closet is amazing. And much more. reviewText:
$14.99 seems like a lot for a game. And yes, in most cases I'd agree with you. However, there are some circumstances in which paying what feels like more-than-average is entirely okay. This is one of those cases.

The Stanley Parable is one of the most original, creative, and though-provoking games (or THINGS, for that matter) I've ever played. Once you finish it, you've finished it. You can go back and do everything as many times as you want, but once you've done it, you've done it.
And that's okay.

I've played this game for about 6 hours (at the time of review) and while I've done pretty much everything there is to do, I've spent hours in reflection of what any of it means. You will learn from this game if you allow yourself to.
It can be silly. It can be unsettling. Most importantly, it can be touching.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. If you're on a budget, waiting wouldn't hurt, but if its on sale for as cheap as it gets (I think around $3.75?), there's no reason not to buy it.

I love this game, and it's made its way into my list of favorites with ease.

P.S. If you don't like the fact that there is (for the sake of this review) no action, and you don't want to spend time listening to the narration, I do NOT recommend it. Its VERY VERY good, yes, but it may not be what some people consider 'fun' (although I presonally had BLAST with it).

reviewText: It truly is hard to put this game into words. At first it may seem like a simple game, you walk, go where you are told, and finish the game. But after a bit of playing, you start to find new ways to play the game, and find it to be much larger than you first imagined. It now seems to be a fun little game, with some silly moments, biting insults, and multiple endings. But as you play the game even more, you start to notice even more things. Like that as you were playing the game, the game was playing you. Every decision you make is manipulated by the game. From the first time you escaped, to your rebellious decision to take the door on the right, to every playthrough after that. You don't play this game, the game plays you.\nEventually you notice something amazing. This isn't even a game. The name states that. It's something much greater than just a game, it's a parable. A parable is a story told to teach a moral lesson. I think this game makes a great parable. But, what lesson does it teach? You'll have to play to find out.\n

reviewText:
A wonderfully philosophical game that if paid the attention it deserves, will make you question just who Stanley really is, just who the narrator really is, and provide deep philosophical questions for you ponder, such as who is really in control of your reality, both as Stanley, and as whoever you are offline.

It may not be who you think it is.

There are no guns and no enemies to kill, no moon nazis or crafting diamond weapons on a crafting table with a hammer. Just philosophical deepness that is unsurpassed in any other game Ive played, but presented in wonderfully engaging way.

This game is not for everyone. It is a very cerebral game at heart, that demands many more hours thinking about the story and how it plays out, than actually playing in it virtually.

The voice acting of Kevan Brighting (Narrator) is also exceptional. It is above and beyond any video game voice work Ive ever heard. IMO, it is now the gold standard to compare other video game voice work to, hands down.

I fully recommend this game to everyone.

reviewText: It truly is hard to put this game into words. At first it may seem like a simple game, you walk, go where you are told, and finish the game. But after a bit of playing, you start to find new ways to play the game, and find it to be much larger than you first imagined. It now seems to be a fun little game, with some silly moments, biting insults, and multiple endings. But as you play the game even more, you start to notice even more things. Like that as you were playing the game, the game was playing you. Every decision you make is manipulated by the game. From the first time you escaped, to your rebellious decision to take the door on the right, to every playthrough after that. You don't play this game, the game plays you.\nEventually you notice something amazing. This isn't even a game. The name states that. It's something much greater than just a game, it's a parable. A parable is a story told to teach a moral lesson. I think this game makes a great parable. But, what lesson does it teach? You'll have to play to find out.\n

reviewText: A pretty fun and unusual game. It's mostly a parody on certain mechanics used in games, most notably the idea of player choice. Well worth it's money.

reviewText:
$14.99 seems like a lot for a game. And yes, in most cases I'd agree with you. However, there are some circumstances in which paying what feels like more-than-average is entirely okay. This is one of those cases.

The Stanley Parable is one of the most original, creative, and though-provoking games (or THINGS, for that matter) I've ever played. Once you finish it, you've finished it. You can go back and do everything as many times as you want, but once you've done it, you've done it.
And that's okay.

I've played this game for about 6 hours (at the time of review) and while I've done pretty much everything there is to do, I've spent hours in reflection of what any of it means. You will learn from this game if you allow yourself to.
It can be silly. It can be unsettling. Most importantly, it can be touching.

I cannot recommend this game highly enough. If you're on a budget, waiting wouldn't hurt, but if its on sale for as cheap as it gets (I think around $3.75?), there's no reason not to buy it.

I love this game, and it's made its way into my list of favorites with ease.

P.S. If you don't like the fact that there is (for the sake of this review) no action, and you don't want to spend time listening to the narration, I do NOT recommend it. Its VERY VERY good, yes, but it may not be what some people consider 'fun' (although I presonally had BLAST with it).

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is just one of those games which people either really like or really dislike; some may feel that they can't do much except freely roam around and listening to a guy talk. However, its beauty lies in the fact that it's entirely oriented about choice. It has some clever humor, and it is generally the type of game where you HAVE to try every single stupid action you can think of, in order to get a reaction from the narrator.

Even if it's a bit short, The Stanley Parable is a great game. If you intend on buying it, I suggest that you try to learn the least possible about it or its story. I would also suggest to play the demo before buying the game (even if you are sure about your decision) : it will help you see if you like that kind of game or not, and it will also provide a good introduction to the actual game if you're going to buy it.

The Stanley Parable is also best played with other people. and it requires a basic, general knowledge of first person video gaming in order to fully get its humor, in some moments.

Have fun!

reviewText: The Stanley Parable is a strange game about the nature of storytelling, video game tropes, and the meaning of free will. But it does make for a very interesting afternoon or two.

reviewText: I sat in broom closet for five minutes, yet remained entertained.  You take that how you like, I'll continue to sit here in my broom closet.  This closet that seems so ordinary, yet urges me to explore it's whole entire four square feet of flooring.  There has got to be something here, I know there is something here.  Maybe in the corner, the papers? No, no, there has to be something here! I'm not leaving until I find it!  You can't make me leave!  I'm not going insane, I'll show you!  If I just sit here, something will happen, something has to happen.  What if nothing really is supposed to happen?  What if I'm just wasting time here? No!  I know there is something here!  I just need to find it!

reviewText:
This is the story of a man named Carbon,

Carbon worked in his own home as a Part-time YouTuber were he was Carbon Helium. Carbon's job was simple: He sat at his desk in his room, and recorded footage of him playing games. Order's came to him via the comments on his videos, telling him what to play, how long, and who with. This is what Carbon did every day, of every month, of every year, and although others might have considered it boring, Carbon relished every moment someone commented on his video, as though he had been made exactly for this job. And Carbon was happy.

And then one day, Carbon downloaded the Stanley Parable, played it for a while, and posted a video on it. Then something very peculiar happened. Something that would forever change Carbon; something he would never quite forget. He had been at his desk for nearly an hour when he realized that not one single comment had been made on his new video. No one had shown up to give him hatred, constructive feedback, or even say 'hi.' Never in all his years at home had this happened, this complete isolation. Something was very clearly wrong.

Shocked, frozen solid, Carbon found himself unable to move for the longest time. But as he came to his wits and regained his senses, he got up from his desk and stepped out of his room.

All of his friends were gone, what could it mean? Carbon then realised he had been playing this game for way too long. That the year was now 2097, and everyone he knew was dead.

10/10, lost all my friends

reviewText: Introspective, hilarious, and dark, this is very much a game ABOUT games.  Above all, it's about the illusion of choice and how a game's narrative is constructed around that. Why can't these people just play my game the way I want them to?  The Stanley Parable is a satire, and an arty" one at that.\n\nBe sure to play the demo

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable is a first person exploration game that makes the player think about the nature of choice in games while simultaneously managing to be a wildly entertaining, hilarious, and surprising experience.
This game has a provocative and perpetual elusiveness that aches to break whatever system it‚Äôs applied to.
The gameplay is quite simple, the graphics and environments are beautiful and the narrative is exquisite.
The Stanley Parable is an incredible piece of self-satirical art that is unlike anything else I ever played and for that, I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
‚ÄúThis is a story of a man named Stanley‚Äù
Premise
In The Stanley Parable, the player takes on the role of a man simply named Stanley. Stanley‚Äôs job is just as simple as his name: an average everyday office worker. The only thing that sounds more boring than Stanley‚Äôs job and name, are his job requirements: press certain buttons as directed by a computer monitor. But don‚Äôt let this boring premise deter you from this game, it‚Äôs brilliant beyond measure.

Despite sounding mindless, Stanley has a passion for his boring office job. Such a mindless passion, that when the orders stop coming in for him to press buttons from the monitor, he waits an entire hour beginning to question the lack of instruction. It‚Äôs this lack of instruction that causes Stanley to become self aware for the first time in his career (and possibly his life), and drives the beginning of the game. It also helps him notice other strange occurrences around the office and makes him ask questions. Where did my co-workers go? Did I miss a memo? Stanley finally has to make his own choices. He has to speak up. He has to think on his own. Where to I walk? What do I interact with? Stanley had been shielded from independent thinking his entire life it appears, all thanks to a computer monitor always telling him what to do. The choices and the independent thinking are where the finally player comes in, and where the excitement of the game is found. Or more accurately, the lack of choice is where the amusement is found. Mwahahahah. Ahem, carrying on.

Bulk of Review
Choices (and the lack of) are undoubtedly the cause of entertainment and humor in this game, but it‚Äôs the way these choices go hand-in-hand with the witty commentary that makes this game truly amusing. Wait, commentary? What commentary? I think it's a point of emphasis that I mention this a narration-driven game. When Stanley finally gains awareness, a narrator begins to narrate Stanley‚Äôs story audibly, remarking his thoughts and actions. The narrator is the one who woke up Stanley from his mindless slumber in the first place. He decides of what happens in the story just as much as the player does. Scratch that-- the narrator is an all powerful omnipotent being who limits the player in every thinkable way possible. That‚Äôs the point of the game in a nutshell.

The thrill of the game is toying with the soothing narrator, who comments on every action and choice the player makes, or for that matter, refuses to make. The narrator not only makes comments, but directs and eventually commands Stanley to go down certain passageways and up certain staircases. He wants to control Stanley as much as you yearn to rebel against him. The true amusement is resisting and compromising with the narrator when he directs you to go down a hallway or through a door. In essence, that is the idea of the game. The struggle for control between the narrator of you and you-- No, not this door, I‚Äôll go through this hallway instead. The narrator‚Äôs frustration and responses with his own character is hilarious and the most thought out part of this game.

The game has very little visual feedback and reinforcement, which can be it‚Äôs downfall and it‚Äôs strength depending on the person. In most cases, I‚Äôd call it a strength. The player can only interact with a handful of objects, which are limited to doors, computers and buttons. This is what makes The Stanley Parable a breath of fresh air. For the first time in my gaming experience, a game relies on the majority of it‚Äôs feedback being audible instead of visual. That‚Äôs a strikingly new concept despite how simple it is to implement and carry out.

If you like the Portal franchise or puzzle games like Antichamber, The Stanley Parable is comparable to a good mix of both, while still maintaining it‚Äôs own personality as a video game. The witty commentary and it‚Äôs amusement that comes with it draws an easy parallel between Portal and The Stanley Parable. If you like GLaDOS‚Äôs company, the game will do a excellent job of keeping you entertained. This game best caters to those who are willing to question everything in the room, and have an eye for patterns and details. The game has a total of 18 different endings depending on how you and the narrator get along, and how well you can think for yourself despite having limited alternatives to what the narrator says.

Some Criticism
So what is this game lacking? Choice. Despite the fact lack of choice is one of the key features of the game, it‚Äôs nonetheless a bit too limited. The vast majority of doors go unlocked and sometimes the player feels very forced into complying with the narrator. Of course, it‚Äôs worth noting the game itself is a analysis on the state of choice in video games. In video games as a medium, we are often more limited with our choices than we care to admit. The Stanley Parable makes light of this. We tend to accept the premise prematurely often too much. We blindly accept the number of choices that are presented, are the number of choices there are. Even with that being the case, the game needs more endings. 18 endings is great, but I feel there is a perfect threshold for this game to capture so it can still make it‚Äôs point about the lack of choice, and have more choice. Perhaps I‚Äôm sour I‚Äôve completed the game and found all the endings, but hey, who wouldn‚Äôt want to rebel against an omnipotent soothing narrator a little more?

Conclusion
Currently, The Stanley Parable goes for a decent $15 on Steam. At best, it will give you 7 hours of gameplay if you‚Äôre sure to analyze every detail. For the average player however, 3 hours is what‚Äôs expected. Due to the nature of the game, it‚Äôs a rainy day experience. And while it has brilliant commentary and thought-provoking critique on the nature of choice in video games, $15 is a bit much for a day‚Äôs worth of entertainment. I‚Äôd strongly recommend waiting for a sale, but if you love Portal and soothing voices, I can empathize if you can‚Äôt.


A Fair Recommendation - 8.7/10

reviewText:
The end is never the end- is never the end, The end is never the end- is never the end, The end is never the end- is never the end, The end is never the end- is never the end...

Not many, if any other games have had me utter the words 'what the f*ck' as many times as this. The Stanley Parable is an icon not to passed up. The devs have done everything possible, added every single variable as to what they assume might be  some ones line of thinking may be. So many ending possibilities, so many different paths to take, so many thrown in pieces of other valve games, it's astonishing and incredible.

I honestly cannot say anything that may spoil this, but question everything, take every single path you can possibly find and you will generally end up with a different outcome.

This game is a masterpiece that is worth every single cent. Seriously, if you've not heard of or played this before... Change that. Play this.

reviewText: I sat in broom closet for five minutes, yet remained entertained.  You take that how you like, I'll continue to sit here in my broom closet.  This closet that seems so ordinary, yet urges me to explore it's whole entire four square feet of flooring.  There has got to be something here, I know there is something here.  Maybe in the corner, the papers? No, no, there has to be something here! I'm not leaving until I find it!  You can't make me leave!  I'm not going insane, I'll show you!  If I just sit here, something will happen, something has to happen.  What if nothing really is supposed to happen?  What if I'm just wasting time here? No!  I know there is something here!  I just need to find it!

reviewText:
All I can tell you about this game is you have to play it. Don't allow yourself to get spoiled reading comments or watching videos on it until you've played it for a while yourself for you must not know what lies within this masterpiece before experiencing it.

The game is wonderful and at many times I found myself laughing like an idiot to myself.

The only downsides are that it's a short game (even for the cost) and that depending on you, you may not find replay value in it. That said, if you have $15 to spare and want a few good hours of fun, highly recommended.

reviewText:
The Stanley Parable- Review

Imagine this game was your grumpy old dad who never ceases to tell you that playing video games is at least as ridiculous as trying to build a snowman out of water.
It basically tells you:
Listen, son. I know you spent some hard-earned-cash on this thing you call a piece of art, but you know what? Games are bloody ridiculous! You're sitting here in front of your PC screen while pressing random buttons just because the game tells you to. You're wasting your precious time! OK, I know that you will never be a rocket scientist or find the cure for cancer, but instead of video games, you should go out and enjoy the beauty of the world we live in.

How do I know that?
Well, for me it's obvious. When you follow all of the narrator's commands , you'll reach an ending where Stanley (and you at the same) shut off the so-called 'mind-control-facility' and then leave it through a garage door leading straight into a bright, greenish landscape. Shortly thereafter you lose control over Stanley who continues walking by himself and then the screen fades to black while you get an achievement that you beat the game.

But the confusing thing about The Stanley Parable is that it also offers you other endings which deal with totally different stuff.After all, it is a game about choice and consequence. Wherever you go changes the ending of the game. While it may be a game which had less budget than an AAA-title, it is by far more complex concerning the story.

The Stanley Parable is worth both your time and your cash. Buy it and let yourself be entertained by this innovative piece of art.
And then don't play it for five years and be rewarded for doing so the day you decide that you want to be Stanley again.

reviewText: Oh lord, what can be said about this game? The Stanley Parable is a gem, it really is. It's one of those games filled to the brim with sublte mystery and -fantastic- narration. Every path you take delivers witty dialogue, clever jokes, and an all-around, genuinely good time. As far as replayability is concerned, well, technically that's what this game is about--you've just got to find all the secrets and endings scattered around here and there, hoping to find something new, testing things you haven't tested before--pushing you to limits of clicking on just about everything--still, once you find satisfaction, picking up this game again might be challenging. For instance, I won't be playing this game for another five years in order to get a certain achievement, and no, I won't be resetting my clock to do so.

reviewText: A perfect blend of confusion, entertainment and odd things. Try to surprise the game, and it will instead surprise you. Can you choose freely, or is the narrator subtly making you do what you do because it's part of his plan?\n\nIt is hard to emphasize the greatness of this game without the risk of spoilers though.
